So far we're upside down on the dream guy, we've undercut the sexual revolution we're purporting to encourage and we haven't even gotten to the worst part: the so-called heroine. Our strong feminine role-model and the ying to Christian's psychotic yang... Ana. This woman is literally surrounded by creepy dudes. Her "friend" photographs her then displays the prints in galleries without her permission intending to sell the photos to strangers (gross). Her boss, first is the guy who goes after the girl even after he knows she has a boyfriend (eww) then that devolves to him trying to freaking rape her in the office. And her boyfriend keeps a freaking file on her, breaks into her house, tries to forbid her from seeing other men, tries to keep her from working, and hires people to find out every personal thing about her and everyone around her ... oh but she LIKES him so that makes it all OK. Come on people this is just sick!Ana is constantly needing to be rescued. Anything she achieves is because someone else notices her not because she goes after anything. She's annoyingly mousy, indecisive, and plays little girl ... oh but don't tell her what to do ... because she's not a sub. She tells Christian to spank her so she's totally in control of the relationship ... except that he's manipulating and controlling her the entire time. And we as an audience are supposed to consider her strong. WHAT? Plus she just rips off the line from Working Girl ... did she know she did that because it seems like she just tried to pass it off as her own. And the rest of the film is like some horrible porn flick with incoherent scenes jumping to more incoherent scenes with excuses for sex scattered every 10 minutes or so just so you're reminded that this is supposed to be hot. There's no cohesion to any of it. There's random gutter girl ... Kim Basinger is Christian's Mrs. Robinson ... a helicopter crashes ... god it's a mess. And on top of ALL of that ... the sex scenes were awful. I thought that was supposed to be the pull of these movies?Please say there won't be a third one of these!

I have read all the books. Twice. America is too conservative for this film. I agree the movie is 'soft porn' to those who like to hide the fact that they sometimes have 'nasty sex'. Everybody has sex, it's human nature. America is throwing a childish tantrum and being hypocritical in it's reception of this movie. That being said, here is my take: Calm the f*ck down. Making a choice to watch this movie is clearly yours alone, if your money feels wasted, then no use crying over spilled milk. I love how unapologetic they were in this one. ALL THE SEX scenes were tastefully done, this movie can not have a story-line without sex. The books are less tame than the movie. Even though it brings a light to certain sexual notions of BDSM, it remains a rated-18 film for only adults to watch. Adults that can't be swayed easily by what they watch, except dumb Americans (in general). Europeans watched this for the entertainment, and the 'love' feel, which the actors did a good job of portraying. I will watch this again because it feeds the pictures i have in my head while reading the novels. The novels do a much better job however. Such judgmental reception of a movie skews quality critique when the only thing people are worried about is their personal feelings when it comes to associating with a potential significant other. It says more about the viewer than the acting or directing.They did way better in this than the first one. I personally felt Christian and Elliot were too skinny in the first one, but they bulked up. All the actors did good. Mia is my only issue, she is supposed to be way curvier, but oh well, I can live with that. Christian is supposed to be more affectionate with Mia; affectionate enough for Ana to notice how different he acts around her. That is one character development that would have added dimension to his character; made him at least a tad redeemable in the eyes of unnecessarily harsh American critique. If it was Brad Pitt... he'd get a better reception, probably outright acceptance. They almost doubled their money, so that means people are watching but no one wants to admit that they watched it, or liked it.Watch this as a guilty pleasure. It may not be true BDSM, but then again it is FICTIONAL. (except your brain can't grasp the meaning of the word).

reviews.review_title: Darker - as in script does not equal book
reviews.content: Saw the movie tonight. I was disappointed to say the least. Sam Taylor-Johnson did a MUCH better job with 50 Shades. This is a LOVE story.For those who have NOT read the novels and/or misunderstood the story here is a correction. This story is NOT ABOUT THE ABUSE OF A WOMAN.Anastasia Steele is the one in Charge. she is much smarter than Christian Grey from the get-go. ANA makes ALL of the decisions about SEX. It is SHE who controls what Christian does to her. If she says NO, he cannot go further: EXAMPLE: at the end of 50 Shades it is ANA who asks to be shown how rough Christian can get. At any time during the 6 strikes of the belt - she could have used her SAFEWORD: RED.She choose NOT TO to have a COMPLETE understanding of how bad Christian's actions were.In that story it is ANA who tells Christian that she wants him. In this story (very poorly re-imagined by the screenwriter) Ana is ALWAYS the one who wants to be ADVENTURSOME.and this is NOT a tale of BDSM. BONDAGE/DOMINATION/SADOMACHISMChristian is damaged from his childhood interactions with his mother's PIMP. He takes those same actions himself: hitting with a belt, tied up, etc.So it is his inner troubled soul seeking LOVE in the ONLY way he has ever know. His mother ignored him and let the pimp beat him; his step mother is a busy doctor and probably had little time for him and showed little love. "Mrs. Robinson" introduced him to his lifestyle by slapping him hard, then f--king him.He grows up, goes to BDSM clubs around Seattle and picks up girls who are into that thing.He only uses Bondage (to keep anyone from touching him) and Domination to control the girls whom he f--ks.The contract (from book 1) specifically excludes ALL of the ROUGH, INHUMANE, AND DISTASTEFUL ACTIONS such as dealing with bodily fluids or other substances, blood, and includes IMMEDIATE CESSATION of actions at the GIRLS request.Ana is in LOVE with Christian and takes on the immense challenge of bringing Christian to adulthood. (he is stuck in a kind of pubescent sexual lifestyle.) The movie script is such a BAD version of the novel that at times it becomes humorless and uninteresting. There is NONE of the fierce passion and drama bursting from the screen that is so well written by the author. They should have kept the original director: Sam Taylor-Johnson - she understood the story and brought it faithfully to the screen.

I saw "Fifty Shades Darker", starring Dakota Johnson-Need For Speed, Crazy in Alabama; Jamie Dornan-The Fall_tv, Once Upon a Time_tv; Kim Basinger-The Nice Guys, Cellular; Marcia Gay Harden-Code Black_tv, Bad News Bears_2005 and Eric Johnson-Rookie Blue_tv, Smallville_tv.This is a sequel to the 2015 erotic hit about love. This one starts pretty much after the last one ended. Dakota is now working at a job publishing books, instead of selling them. Jamie shows up professing his love for her and telling her that he will do anything to get her back, even if it is on her terms. You know, maybe a little less S&M in the red room. She tells him they will try and take things slow & easy. Yeah, right. It's not long before they are going at each other as if they were in a soft porn movie. Eric plays Dakota's boss at her new job and I have never read the books but I have a feeling that Eric will play a bigger part in Chapter 3, due out in theaters around Valentines' Day 2018. There are some females that show up from Jamie's past; one is an ex submissive that has gone a little psycho and the other is the 'Mrs Robinson' that taught Jamie a thing or two in the bedroom-Mrs Robinson is played by Kim. Marcia plays Jamie's stepmother. Oh yeah, there is a helicopter crash which causes matters to escalate. If you liked the first one then you should like this one, too. I thought it was a little better than the first one. When the end credits start, don't get up and leave just yet. There is a teaser trailer for the 2018 'Fifty Shades Freed', the third installment. It's rated "R" for language and strong erotic sexual content-including graphic nudity-and has a running time of 1 hour & 58 minutes. It's not one that I would buy on DVD-one viewing was enough-but it would be alright as a rental.

Fifty Shades DarkerIt's a safe bet that being tied up in bed is the sexual fetish of every escape artist.However, the subservient in this erotic drama isn't exactly dislocating her shoulder.While she is working as an assistant book editor, Anastasia (Dakota Johnson) attends an art event where she runs into her wealthy ex-boyfriend/dominate Christian (Jamie Dornan), who wants her back.She quickly agrees to rekindle their kinky relationship but under one condition: no more punishment. Meanwhile, Christian's former submissive (Bella Heathcote) and his mature mentor (Kim Basinger) both reappear in his life to wreak havoc on his current affair.While it is twice as titillating as the initial soft-core film adaptation of E. L. James's erotic bestseller, this superfluous sequel still lacks a semi-interesting storyline, skilled actors to portray the flimsy characters and dialogue that isn't completely ridiculous.Incidentally, BDSM paraphernalia can also be used a weapon against home invaders. Red Lightvidiotreviews.blogspot.ca

reviews.review_title: Bad and not in the good way..
reviews.content: There was no story. It was sex scene after sex scene. Ugh. So much potential that they wasted. No wonder so many folks involved with the first film declined to participate in the second or third movies. Jamie Dornan is easy on the eyes as Christian Grey but with no story the movie just falls flat.

reviews.review_title: Unintentionally funny and entertaining if you don't take it seriously
reviews.content: This movie was hilarious at times, even more than the first one. It must be the element of suspense that was added which in terms of plot development fell short. The thing that is actually on point is the cinematography. The film is well shot, providing some nice scenes and the flow is good. For some reason the first one was better. I think it has to do with the over-hype that surrounded its release but i believe it was more coherent and more decent as a result. Also the soundtrack music was infinitely better. The sequel's OST is atrocious. Every single song was cringe-worthy bubblegum pop that ruined whatever mood they tried to set in, particularly in the sex scenes. There was zero eroticism in the sex scenes. They were rushed, watered down, and even boring for a so called "erotic book" adaptation. Ironically Christian encourages Ana to come but of course it ends before we can have a glimpse of her orgasm. The silver balls scene provides so much laughter it's hard to dismiss that one, though. The plot is laughable as a whole. We have 3 "villains" who are as menacing as a piece of broccoli and they offer nothing but pointless drama. The whole thing is more of a soap opera than a thriller. Christian's past isn't developed enough to make the audience to care and Ana is just too passive and compliant. When she attempts to stand up for herself Christian shuts her up with a kiss or with a fancy present. He's always overbearing, controlling, and pretty much wants her to be mute and obedient. He does a ton of offensive things that would require a restraining order but all is well when we proposes to her or takes her out to sailing. The romance is as flat as an ironing board and the actors don't do anything to convince us that these two love each other. The biggest fail of this movie was the helicopter scene. Christian's family looked like they were kinda relieved he went missing and the heart-stopping suspense lasts for one scene until Christian casually walks into his apartment with blood on his forehead like some superhero who miraculously crawled out of the crushed helicopter and arrived in Seattle two hours later unharmed. Lol. The final scene features Ana's boss who looks like a homeless junkie and sets up the story-line for the final movie in which he'll be the main villain. Overall if you try to look for interesting characters and situations you'll find none here. This is a film made just for laughter and nothing else. If you want quality you will be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: Never going to get the time back.....
reviews.content: I hate the fact i ever watched the first one, my addictive persona does not allow me to stop watching a series till its done...its a lost, twilight, fast and the furious hell! Boy is this film stale bread! Clunky and ridiculous. Dakota needs to take a page from Marcia Gays book she can actually cry when required not just scrunch her face up like a discarded chocolate bar wrapper. Kim Basinger should have been in it more...you have a diamond like her and show her off for 30secs at the end, tut tut! I was surprised Kim B was in it actually being the star of 9 1/2 weeks and fifty shades being a complete rip off of it, as well as the Secretary of course. There's definitely some other films thrown in there. I think that's where the author got her inspiration, a girls night in with a bottle of red, an ip dip do on chick flicks laced with James Spader and Mickey Rouke...and maybe a secret Santa joke present in the form of a vibrator. Jamie Dornan is an Irish dream boat, he's still developing as an actor but he predominantly carries the film. That's why he has to be so ripped, hes just dragging the whole thing behind him..'come on Dakota, pick up your lip its causing drag, Rita...where are you going? Stop running around in circles and get back here', "Hi, Ho, Hi Ho" JamieI think this film restricts his potential and its a shame his interactions with Marcia and Kim couldn't have been longer, as i think we could have seen the dual personality of this potentially good and complex character. But nooo, a big steamy dollop of manure was the final outcome...sorry Jamie but not even with your muscles could you drag this dung heap to the Oscars/baftas!

I think that this was a great film with a better developed story and a cast that was at ease with each other.While I liked Fifty Shades of Grey, I think that Fifty Shades Darker delved a little deeper into the story. While the first movie was mostly about Ana and her sexual awakening, this was about Christian and his realization that you need more than just sex.You could plainly see that both Dakota and Jamie were also more at ease with each other. None of their scenes felt forced or hindered by a lack of trust or friendship that you could see in the first movie.While many are bagging this movie for not being a cinematic masterpiece, I believe that they take movies way too seriously and that Fifty Shades Darker is a great piece of entertainment.

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies ever made?
reviews.content:
Can't tell this is the the worst movie ever made? Or Sex and the city or anything Sarah Jessica Parker was in? Hard to choose. Acting was worse than directing and directing was worse than screenplay, of course directing was worse than acting which was worse than screenplay.
No bout it's one of the worst movies ever made.

reviews.review_title: Corny but what romance film isn't
reviews.content: I read the book a long time ago. So I know what is going on. And to me I loved this movie a lot. I got to laugh and cry a little. Jamie and Dakota actually did a better job than the first movie. Which I thought was horrible directed.I really loved this movie and the music. I thought was really great. EL James really knew her stuff. I am one point thought she directed the movie because it was really good.I know critics hated this movie but we the fans don't care. The movie was for us fans that enjoyed a romance film. Between character that had respect for each other.

The movie is okay, don't know why people are giving it ratings bellow what its worth, I don't see anything wrong with it, nice story line and good, only that I was expecting Anna to make it difficult to accept Grey back even if she was going to accept him back after she saw the real devil in him at the first part. By the way love the O.S.T. i don't wanna live forever performed by Zayne and Taylor Shift

Okay, so my expectations were not high since the first one was not exactly "Citizen Kaine" nor were the books literary masterpieces, but this film is laughably bad, and surprisingly, rather dull!! So, what exactly is wrong with this film? Where to even start... the screenwriter, for one, who seems like they just took up writing for fun a few weeks before shooting the film. Some of the lines are absurd - and not even original!!! Look out for a line in the film stolen, verbatim, from Dakota's mom Oscar-winning hit film, "Working Girl." The biggest difference between those two films? Melanie Griffith was Oscar- nominated for her role in "Working Girl." Dakota Johnson will be lucky to get a Razzie award. A high school student who picked up any knowledge of sex or anatomy from science class, or who had any grasp of the English language, could have done a better job writing this script. The new director also seemed in a real hurry to crank this film out-everything is so rushed and confused. Probably the most obvious issue is the acting. Jaime Dornan was good in "The Fall" but in this role, he has all the charisma of a cardboard box. He's supposed to be the man of every woman's dreams??? I'd be surprised if after this film franchise wraps he ever manages to land a good role again- in my opinion, this film and this role has pretty much wrecked any chances he'd have of a strong career. Charlie Hunnam is probably thanking his lucky stars he managed to get out of appearing in this wreck! To go from "Sons of Anarchy" to this mess of a franchise would have been a huge mistake. Dakota Johnson fares a little bit better than Dornan, but honestly that is not saying much since he is so unappealing in this role. The two also have ZERO chemistry on screen! For a film that's supposed to be some kind of great sexy film, these two actors have absolutely ZERO chemistry. Rather than feel any kind of spark when they were on screen together, I found myself sometimes cringing. Kim Basinger is a good addition to this film, and she is still radiantly beautiful and appealing on screen, but she is given very little to do here. It's too bad that she wasn't the lead- I was more interested in her character than I was in either of the lead characters. Unless you are a huge fan of the books, I'd recommend waiting to watch this on basic cable.

reviews.review_title: Amazing Movie Better Than The First!!!
reviews.content: This was a really good movie didn't expect this movie to be that good this movie was even better than the first one it had more sexual scenes in it than the first one the first one had like 2 this one had like 6 and im glad they got more of those scenes in there because it ain't a fifty shades movie unless it has a lot of that and it did so it was really good in that part and the story was really good as well it got really good into the story of it than the first one there are new things in this one than the other and i really like how they played the story out in this one this one has a lot of story to it which i like the first one didn't have as much and there was nothing really at all to fault about this movie it was really good so im gonna rate it a 10/10 because i couldn't find anything to fault so it was a really good movie and i recommend anyone seeing it just except a lot of nudity lol.

The next installment of E.L James' Fifty Shades trilogy features more lip-biting, leg-grabbing, cash-flashing drivel than ever before; which doesn't amount to anything more than a lack of ingenuity.The saucy sequel to the novel-turned-movie epidemic that is Fifty Shades of Grey, this adaptation was a concise continuation of the first - glossy, well-polished, and truly tedious. Though funny at points, and extraordinarily easy to keep up with, the persistent lack of chemistry between the mediocre leads made the film about as raunchy as your grans' knickers.While the franchise has established a rather successful position within the market (having made almost $150m on its' opening weekend alone), the sex-fuelled romance between the very plain Ana (Dakota Johnson) and billionaire bachelor Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan) sees demons confronted and emotional deviations from the start.Dornan, while definitely more polished than his previous performance, still lacked energy and relate-ability, while Johnson was an irritatingly deficient component in her reprisal. The remainder of the cast (including an over-hyped Rita Ora) were about as unmemorable as you would expect. The introduction of various faces (Mrs Robinson, unfortunately not portrayed by Kim Cattrall) added nothing exceptional either.The cinematography which, although well-suited to the style of the story, didn't strike me as anything special whatsoever. This time around however, the music was also particularly bland in comparison to Fifty Shades of Grey - which at least complimented the picture.There isn't much to be said for the writing or direction - sex is Darkers' only narrative, which, by the end, borders on ridiculous. It still can't work out if it wants to be a classic love story or a steamy depiction that verges on pornographic - either way their brief has been ineffective.Overall, a middle-of-the-road love story; well-adapted though poorly executed, with occasional steamy moments but hardly tugging at the heart-strings. Boring and bland - I can't wait to be Freed from this trilogy.http://showme-themovies.blogspot.co.uk/
5/10 - continuing with a stellar soundtrack and a sliver more story, Fifty Shades Darker is the rare sequel that outshines its predecessor

reviews.review_title: Heart breathtakingly beautiful.. The ending made me swoon
reviews.content: Okay Fifty shades darker ripped my heart out and stomped on it in more ways than one. Christian Grey made a complete 180 from the first film. (side note) I have read the books and Grey which is FSOG in Christian's POV! I loved seeing Ana and Christian grow together as well as separately. It was nice seeing a bits of Christian's backstory, the third movie we will get to see some more i expect. Since that's what happened in the novels. the ending with Christian popping the question melted my heart and make me swoon. I can't wait for February 9th 2018 Fifty shades Freed... I think I'll have to reread the books!
This is probably the most underrated movie I've ever come across. Getting so much hate. Well, people just don't get it.

As we all know these books have been adored and trashed by people all around the world. Honestly, I've read only this part out of sheer curiosity, given that the first one was actually a bit fascinating, albeit a tad unrealistic. Then again, the pleasure that this series has given is always about seeing beautiful people on screen doing things we hoped that in real life could actually happen to us.Continuing straight from the end of the first movie, Ana has moved on with her life and is now working in a publishing company at Seattle. One day, a huge bouquet of white roses was delivered to her house and it's from... you guessed it... Christian. They happened to meet in an art exhibition and he wanted to start over. And this time, no rules, no punishment, and no more secrets. Unfortunately for them, a woman from Christian's past emerged, including his former lover and there's another problem with Ana's new (handsome) boss.Let's just get this out of the way; this movie is a pure guilty pleasure. The story is not that substantial to begin with. It's built as a side attraction to the main event; the sex scenes. And let me tell you, It's more graphic than the first one, it could be considered as porn with a much higher budget. You may think the plot is more dense and that there's going to be so much going on when in fact, there's not much. What I find quite lacking is the dramatic tension. All the conflicts they've brought up in this movie were finished so quickly and without much effort. It's like they're rushing to get to the next sex scene which there are quite aplenty.All that said, the actors are really giving their best. Dakota Johnson, just like in the first one, lights up the screen with her quirky attitude and real vigor. And I found Jamie to be more nuanced in his role here, even though he was given less material to work with than Dakota. The others were game enough but didn't give much impression than the leads.Another thing I have to say is that the screenplay is actually better than its' predecessor, and it's written by the author's husband, Niall Leonard. They actually make it quite funny and intentionally funny (contradictory to the movie title). Yet, any attempt at depth is almost nonexistent. The funny thing is that the book provides more information about Christian's past whereas here it got glossed over with only small glimpses of them.James Foley, who once worked in another erotic movie 'Fear', brought all the glitz and glam to the movie, giving it a very beautiful look. Hell, even the cinematography is so gorgeous, it could pass for an Oscar nomination.All things considered, if you really want to find two hours for an escape from real life, this is your ticket. Don't even expect to get an insight or the bigger meanings of life from watching this movie.

reviews.review_title: So little (or too much?) in so much
reviews.content: "Fifty Shades Darker" is a new American film from this year that runs for a massive 2 hours and 10 minutes in the uncensored version. It is the sequel of course to "Fifty Shades of Grey" and experienced filmmaker James Foley took over here as director and he will also return in making the final(?) third film. The writer is Niall Leonard and it is surprising to see him in charge of such a prestigious movie script, but then again maybe they did not get anybody better to adapt the work by E.L. James as many thought this project was doomed from the very beginning and the bad literary work cannot be turned into a quality film. But I haven't read the book, so who knows. Anyway, Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan return of course playing the central characters and so do some of the others like Oscar winner Marcia Gay Harden. But there are also new characters like Kim Basinger's. Yep, another Oscar winner! However, the story is a mess. Let me explain my title now. For huge parts of the film, nothing was happening at all and then they rush in gunpoint scenes, plane crashes, marriage proposals etc. as if there was no tomorrow. Focus and balanced story-telling are completely nonexistent.Overall, the film is not a failure, but equally forgettable as the first. As a heterosexual male, I cannot deny that Johnson is still pretty gorgeous, even if I had some doubts about it in the first half. But sadly, the film is never on par with her looks. It's the same like the first film with the two protagonists trying to establish a relationship that satisfies them both with his desire for domination and her desire for normalcy. And then there are moments when she wants to be dominated and moments when he is normal, so trouble and conflict are simply inevitable. But these scenes are not enough of a foundation to construct a good film on. And the character writing is also disappointing as the ways in which they depict former lovers as evil, potential lovers (the boss) as evil and friends and family as good. Even Mr. Grey has zero shades and the title is a lie. His actions are so predictable for example that he only accepts the men in Ana's life who don't pose a danger from the romantic perspective. Then again, of course she wants nobody other than Grey anyway. The film is a kitschy movie with the only difference to romantic garbage films that it depicts some extremes. But none of it is handled competently and the result is a very bland 130 minutes you don't want to check out. Clearly a thumbs-down from me. Not recommended.

Sorry but I'm a big fan I love the books but I cant lie about this one. Personal opinion: 50 shades darker is the first movie that I end up paying $20 to go see & the biggest disappointment ever. Waiting years and it looked like the director didn't even bother to read the books, went short on money and they forgot to hire a writer to finish the script. Plus the actress needs some acting classes or stop acting all together because my God she was like a birth control pill.I personally think that the first one was a much better produced and the chemistry between the character was more realistic. To me in this second movie it was a lack of chemistry and the movie as a hole was not the best for such a high profile movie.

When I seen fifty shades of Grey I thought even though it didn't stay too true to the book it was a very good movie...then darker came out I waited two years since the first movie and to me it was way worth the wait I freaking loved this movie the characters seemed more comfortable with each other and the acting of Ana was much much better I was impressed and Christian put on some weight but not only that the other characters to me was more interesting like Mrs Lincoln and Leah was so good I just wished u seen more of Ana and Jose and Kate and Elliot that was the only problem for me but Christian was much more convincing in the film so intense loved him and the sex scene oh my I just blushed again...😊😜 I truly enjoyed this film but I do recommend people if your not into BDSM and you haven't read the books then don not see the film

reviews.review_title: This is the same as the books.
reviews.content: I loved the books and was looking forward to the movies. It was not as steamy as the book but it was still artfully filmed. The actors grew well through the film and played well to each other. I enjoyed the movie as a story of two people finding each other and working their way throughout many differences.

Fifty Shades Darker is much better than Fifty Shades of Grey. The tone is better, the mood is better, the editing is better, acting is better and the chemistry is better. It's not perfect. But it is judged unfairly. It never pretends to be an Oscar movie. It is an average love story. The source material was widely criticized for either promoting abuse of woman, or labeled as being "mommy porn". Simply put it is a story written for women by a woman. It is an honest reflection of a character in an unhealthy relationship, with no filters. As a filter obsessed society, we judge when things are without filters, but secretly we crave and embrace the honesty. #NoFilter. Because it was so widely embraced in secret by women, it was labeled as being "porn". To make it less, and to make woman feel dirty and pathetic for enjoying it. The story as a whole is a simple love story. A woman falls in love with a man that was deeply scarred as a child. Physically abused by his mothers' boyfriend, abandoned and neglected by his mother. Surviving for 3 days with his mothers corps. Taken in by a loving family. Never dealing with his past, becoming a troubled teenager. Sexually abused and turned into a sadist by an older woman. Heavy stuff. When the only woman that ever saw the real him, runs away in fear. He evolves to win her back(People don't change, they can only evolve). The movie touched on all the topics mentioned above, but in my opinion it wasn't dramatic enough. It never builds, and it kind of falls flat. I have read the books, and I think my expectations were a little high. I expected it to be intense and dramatic, given the subject matter. unfortunately the movie runs horizontal. I would have combined the 2nd and 3rd books. The story line in Darker doesn't have enough substance as a stand alone movie. but having said that it was hot, steamy and sexy. and as a 2nd movie in a trilogy it carries the story forward.

reviews.review_title: could have been a better plot
reviews.content: Fifty Shades Of Grey was more exciting, a lot of publicity and as it was the the first episode people tended to rush to the theaters. However, Fifty Shades Darker has more sex scenes and a more foreseen story. there could have been more exciting scenes. Overall I did not like it.

reviews.review_title: If you're a fan, watch the movie.
reviews.content: First things first... this movie is a total guilty pleasure and I do not think it is meant for the Oscar category so the other reviewers can calm down on that subject. If you have read the trilogy of the books I would suggest to watch the movies. They obviously can't fit everything in the movie that is in the book let's be realistic it's never happened and it never will! I don't understand why people who write the reviews that say "went to this movie as a joke or because I was forced" and then continue to give a bad review.... you actually sound ridiculous and good for you for doing that to yourself lol. Anybody who is anybody knows what type of movie this is. I would never go to a movie that I knew wasn't in any interest of mine. Aside from all that. I thought the movie was great! They did a really good job of bringing your imagination from the books to the screen. I like FSD the most because it has the most to tell in the trilogy. The characters personalities come out more and we get to meet new characters which give a suspenseful twist to the movie! Can't wait to see Freed!

Why did Anastasia get back with Christian? I mean she is so bad for him. She is so controlling and messed up in the head. He on the other hand is upfront with his kinkiness. It is a movie where Cuckoo meets kinky. Cuckoo wants kinky to change but kinky never will and deep down they both know it but live in frustrating denial. Only one more movie to go and we can breath easy because there will be no more books to base the movie on. However that has not stopped Hollywood before like the Jurassic park and Jaws sequels. So I am afraid the whiny dumbasses are here to stay and we cannot do sh!t about it except whine and moan like they do.

If you can say anything nice about 50 Shades Darker it's that, unlike its odious predecessor, it at least doesn't tack on some faux "liberated woman" bulls**t in the feeble hopes of shutting down naysayers. Adding something to that effect at the end of this stinker would have been the equivalent of saying "don't tinkle in public," right after electrocuting yourself on an electric fence, fly first. Also, while we're on the subject of niceties, another good thing about this movie is it endseventually.Anastasia Steele (D. Johnson), our milquetoast protagonist from the last film is at it again with her manipulative, controlling, borderline psychotic, billionaire boyfriend, Christian Grey (Dornan). Only this time, the only safety word we're given is "change". As in, "I'm a changed man," and/or "you need to change," or (if you ignore the theatrical release and find this garbage on Cinemax) "change the channel." Anastasia is convinced the Christian does desire to be a little less sadistic and does have it in him to change; and if we follow the cues of director David Foley, it seems the movie wants to convince us he can.There's a side plot involving a former "submissive" (Heathcote) who was gaslighted by Grey long ago, but for the most part we're stuck in the bloated doldrums of Christian and Anna's airless relationship. Their relationship includes such emotional highlights as: angry text messages, excessive brooding, frustrating secrecy and Christian pulling out all the stops to literally buy his paramour. The film then takes great pains to elevate every tiny independent choice Anastasia makes into some epic act of defiance comparable to Kunta Kinte on the whipping pole. Reality is, it's just a concentrated dose of rich white people problems pureed and injected into the faces of willing audiences like Botox.But of course, this movie is not for me. I'm about as far from the prime demographic as you can get (the prime demo of course being aliens piecing together what exactly happened before the Earth was destroyed). Those interested in seeing the sequel to a film based on a book, based on Twilight fan-fiction, are only interested in one thing. I'll give you a guess as to what that is.Well far be it from me to disagree with the middle-aged women sitting behind me smelling of cheap perfume and Peppermint Schnapps but I really doubt everyone got their money's worth this time around. This movie is not only an insult to fiction publishers, the Seattle skyline, helicopters, the S&M subculture and whatever the f**k Christian Grey actually does for a living, 50 Shades Darker is an insult to good smut. At least good smut gives you the goods. This movie and the filmic atrocity before it gives you the thirty second sample version of what you actually want and fills the rest of the time with blank stares, lacy corsets and complete misunderstanding of human anatomy.The 50 Shades series (2012-Present), despite being horrid in every conceivable way has still managed so far to scrounge enough fans for further movies. To them I ask, would Christian Grey still appeal to you if he had a bank account to match his IQ? Would you still want this character tracing his abs with lipstick then? They say that the difference between erotica and porn is the lighting. I think I would have rather been left in the dark on this series.

I just came here by curiosity after watching the original and was wondering how much hatred would have accumulated over the sequel. Well I had to go through quite a few comments this time to see anything positive about it. I can't judge because I have not seen this "Darker" sequel. But I'm not surprised about the result at all! One short comment I enjoyed was one that said "Why did you spend another couple of hours to see it if you did not like the first one" Indeed what did these people expect, a reformed story "a la Brady Bunch"? But some can't help themselves then complain of a raw deal! With my French background I came across an interesting outcome. Where I live now I encountered 2 people who got married the wife was absolutely engrossed with anything French where the husband did not have a single positive feeling about this country or its people...They went to Paris for their honeymoon. When they returned he hated the place and its people even more, where as her attraction for it had grown much greater. Please if you one who can't say anything good about both "50 shades", do us a favour - Skip the 3rd one if there was ever to be one

reviews.review_title: No rules. No Punishment. No Secrets.
reviews.content: I was not a fan of the first film and admit this was an improvement in character development. Christian (Jamie Dornan) comes crawling back to Anna (Dakota Johnson), this time, "no rules, no punishment, no secrets." But don't fret, if the only reason you watched the first film is to see Dakota get handcuffed, slapped around and taken from behind, it still happens. We discover more about Christian in this film as Anna attempts to end his possessiveness and need to control her. Appearing in the film is Bella Heathcote who looks like Anna giving me flashbacks to SWF. Their physical appearance is part of Christian's psyche.The film still suffers as did the first one as neither Dakota Johnson nor Jamie Dornan can act. They were cardboard in their roles. Kim Basinger of "9 1/2 Weeks" is suitable for her role as Elena, yet in the film I was bored by her too. I don't know if the characters were this wooden in the book, but they needed to do something for the film.Guide: F-word, sex, nudity

reviews.review_title: Terrible dialogue, acting, direction, and a barely noticeable plot.
reviews.content: Fifty Shades Darker is the second film in its exotic romantic drama series that is worse than the last movie. Even with the change in writer/director with Niall Leonard and James Foley handling the second installment. The film has a terrible script; direction, and Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan stale performances tend to continue. The plot was eh, if there was one. I will say the soundtrack with the varieties of artists is probably the only positive thing about the movie. The plot continues with Christian Grey (Jamie Dornan) trying to get Anastasia (Dakota Johnson) to go back with him. (After things did not end well in the previous movie). Ana now working at a new job with a boss Jack (Eric Johnson) that is trying to flirt with her. Ana decides to give Grey another chance. Soon, Grey's past comes back to haunt after him with Leila (Bella Heathcote) stalking Ana and Christian. If you are into the cliché romantic drama movies, than sure this may be for you. Or if you are looking for some steamy erotic sex scenes with Grey's BDSM lifestyle, then this may also be for you. It is difficult to find this film to be any good with its poor plot. Ana is trying to become an independent woman. Trying to have that backbone. When Grey is trying to get her to go back with him, she tells him they need to take it slow. A follow up scene, than shows her caving in for his needs. Which makes this whole movie with Ana trying to have control but a scene later, she and Grey are in bed together. There was no real conflict with this complicated relationship they are having. It tries to have this build up of Grey willing to try to work on himself and his habits for her. But there was no progression on him working it out. Grey is a man that is psychologically damaged after a past with an incident with his mother. The BDSM is his way of escaping his pain, which Elena (Kim Basinger) has showed him in his earlier years. But the plot has no real conflict when it focuses with Ana and Grey going back and forth with trying to take it slow and than rushing into some kinky sex. The script was horrible with some laughable cheesy dialogue. Like "Kinky F***ery." Some made up one-liners that is so bad but laughable. The direction was dull, those steamy sex scenes were made to get a rise out of a certain audience but it was nothing really special about it. The acting was bad with Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan. Literally feels like they are bored with their characters. Johnson is a beautiful decent actress but her performance that is so monotone and yet very passive in the movie is irritating and unattractive. The positive aspect of the film, which did not help the movie. It did have a great soundtrack that worked on certain scenes like the "I don't wanna live forever" by Zayn and Taylor Swift. And "Not afraid anymore" by Halsey. Overall, Fifty Shades Darker is a bad exotic film that is meant to be locked up in a dark room and forgotten. But for the fans of the novels, they may get a kink out of the movie and possibly excited for a third hopefully final movie. I do not recommend the film if your not a fan of the novels.

Loved it, I went to see with my wife. We both rate it a 10.Full of sexy passion and romance. Puts other movies in this genre to shame.We also enjoyed the first one. The leading actors were fantastic.We did read the books together and found the movie bought to life the books perfectly. Will be looking forward to the next one and watching again on Blu-ray.So stupid the bad reviews from people who didn't enjoy the first one why would they go see the second one just to have a moan. Perfect movie.

reviews.review_title: Really enjoyed this film.why all the bad reviews!?
reviews.content: I have read all the books and watched the films and Iv got to say I expected the worst dueto the terrible reviews.But I was pleasantly surprised by this film.It was fast paced and to the point and not much sex which was good.As the books do go over similar sex scenes far too much.When you read a book you do have high expectations as you have a scene etc in your head but this film did not disappoint.

What a person thinks of this movie depends on what he thinks is the intent, if that intent is well-done and whether or not the intent is worth doing in film. In this case, we have 10 or so sex scenes set within a larger drama. The larger drama is the pursuit of the billionaire of Anastasia Steele and the pursuit of the fiction editor where Miss Steele works of her as well.Writers could create a movie of Romeo and Juliet either with or without a sex scene and with differing emphasis on the sex scene. Depending on the depiction of possible sex in Romeo and Juliet, the question would arise as to what intent a writer might have.Is the point of 50 shades darker to tell us the story of the pursuit or to show us the 10 (or so) sex scenes while we think we are seeing the story of the romantic pursuit of Miss Steele?In this case, the background drama is tolerable and somewhat OK . . . and there are 10 or so sex scenes which are intriguing and interesting. The sex scenes include semi-public fondling in an elevator, Anna's stimulation by pleasure balls at a masked ball, the use of a leg restraint to flip over Anastasia to set her up for sex and various shots of Anna in lingerie or nude.I think the plot is mostly dumb, at times somewhat irrational, but the sex and nudity was good and fun . . . and that makes the movie worthwhile, that alone. So, a person might ask, What information is a spoiler for the movie? Is it that Christian Grey asks Steele to marry him and she says yes after holding him in suspense and also believing that he will succeed at being a better person? Or . . . is it 10 sex scenes along the way?

I enjoyed the movie. It's definitely a chick flick. 80% of the people at my showing were female. While critics have complained about the acting and script, my complaint was make-up and set design.The Christian Grey character now has a scruffy face. I'm not a fan, but a lot of people like that look. The problem is, the scruff varied wildly in the film, both in length and color. Now if the time period between scenes was days or weeks, this isn't a problem. If the time period is a few hours, there should be little change. I found I could tell when episodes were filmed just by looking at the scruff. The make-up department wasn't looking at stills from previous filming to match things up.The set design was also irritating. The Christian Grey penthouse seemed to have undergone a complete redecoration between book 1 and book 2. Same with Anastasia's apartment. This is such a silly error. Look at stills from first film, rebuild, use on second film.

reviews.review_title: Even De Vinci in the 1400's used the naked body as an art form
reviews.content: Fifty Shades Darker 2017 is about a 27 year old man who had a drug addict as a mother who died when he was 4 years old and then when he was taken to the hospital after the mother's body was found by the Medical staff, he was adopted into a family. Somehow along the way he became a billionaire. He owns many businesses and companies in America and throughout the world. He meets his ex-girlfriend at a photography exhibition where her pictures are on display. He buys all the photographs on display of her in the exhibition. He convinces her to go to dinner with him and after a bit of give and take, she accepts.Christian, the lead character, has had relationships with 2 other women in the past. Kim Basinger and another younger woman. Both women appear to still love Christian a lot and are having a hard time letting Christian go. Anastasia and Christian have a relationship, which leads to moving in together which leads to a marriage proposal which Anastasia accepts. This is the case in point story. On a Meta level, this movie is about abuse and Christian. Christian was abused as a child by his mother and there is a flashback in the movie about his father abusing him too. Christian has cigarette burns on his body and he does not like his torso to be touched, in most cases. He uses his sexual organs as a form of defense mechanism to release his swelling up tensions and stress-levels. According to the 2 ex-girlfriends that pop up in the movie, Christian needs to have a submissive sexual relationship; submissive means in the sexual context but also in the everyday life context. Anastasia appears to desperately want to give this to Christian. This movie has clear female roles and males roles. Christian, the male, takes charge in every way whereas Anastasia is submissive to his needs, for example by not going with her boss on a publications trip to New York. Christian both controls and terrorizes Anastasia's life and Anastasia allows and welcomes this kind of control from him, this is often the Hollywood female role in Hollywood movies. Christian wants to be saved by Anastasia and Anastasia wants to both be the savior and the submissive with a master in her actions with Christian. The relationship that Christian and Anastasia share is a co-dependent relationship; as each person does not seem to be whole and content within their selves. Instead, they need each other to fill the other ones' inner void. In the movie, this concept seems to be both romantic and totally acceptable however in real-life this could possibly lead to disastrous domestic sexual violence. This movie has been rated 18A for adult, and often movies I think should come with an announcement in the beginning of the movie, stating that movie is fiction. It is not-reality, but in fact an art-piece. Sometimes movies can taint reality and paint an unfair picture of what love looks like, so it is advisable to watch this movie through the eyes of an art-critical or film critical versus through the eyes of an audience member who believes this movie reflects our current day society, the roles of men and women in relationship and how love should look like today. As this really is not the case at all. This is a fantasy adult movie. An art flick only.

reviews.review_title: Won me over with its sweetness and charm
reviews.content: "Fifty Shades of Grey" was the film everyone loved to hate. Chris Stuckmann, my absolute favorite critic, destroyed it, awarding it an "F" grade. Me, being the ever-diligent movie aficionado, decided to go see the movie anyway. And in all honestly, I was looking forward to watching it. When the first trailer surfaced, I was surprised by how good it looked. Incredibly shot with a fantastic music choice, the preview made the movie look more like a thriller than a romance. So on Valentine's Day of 2015 I walked in the theatre, plastic wrap all over the floor like Dexter's kill room, and found myself to be the only single male there. Everyone else in the 300 seat theatre, and I do mean everyone, was either with a date or with a group. Now I'm not sure if you've ever seen a widely released erotic BDSM soft core pornography film in a packed theatre by yourself, but let me tell you that it's not the most comfortable experience, especially when everyone else around you is breathing heavily and leaving every 15 minutes to use the restroom (seriously, those people had the weakest bladders). When the credits rolled not only did I find my shoes somehow soaking wet, but I realized that the movie was actually, well, not bad!I was surprised. This was "Fifty Shades of Grey?" This was the movie that users on IMDb rated so low that it had a 3.2 even before it came out? This was the movie Chris Stuckmann gave an "F" to and Jeremy Jahns gave his lowest rating of "dogsh*t" to? Complex characters filled the screen, an interesting story unfolded before your eyes, and a blossoming romance was born. I'm not ashamed to say I liked "Fifty Shades of Grey," so of course I was ready for "Fifty Shades Darker."And of course the critics of the world stomped the movie under their boot. But that wasn't going to stop me from taking my grandma to watch this movie with me. I take film criticism very seriously, and damn it, I'm a sucker for romance (and I know how much grandma loves her bondage). So with all that said, how was "Fifty Shades Darker?" The first words that pop into my head are "sweet," "charming," and "romantic." This movie won me over with how sweet its romance was between Anastasia and Christian. Christian, played by Jamie Dornan, is desperately in love with Anastasia, and that comes across very clear. Mr. Dornan's acting is believable and I wouldn't be surprised if the two actors had something going on during filming as well.Dakota Johnson as Anastasia was excellent. I don't want to bash Jamie Dornan's acting ability at all, because he is a fine actor, but Dakota Johnson acts waves across Jamie. Her portrayal of Anastasia Steele is incredible, filled with a shy anxiety and nervous love; she is truly a joy to watch on screen. And man, she is beautiful. I'm telling you, if news broke out that Jamie and Dakota fell in love during the making of this film I wouldn't doubt it.But there isn't just romance in this movie. There are some mild thriller elements here and there and it adds a lot of variety to the film. There are creepy stalkers, misogynistic bosses, and old flames trying to sow discord, and it was all so entertaining to watch. There's a fantastic scene with Christian and one of his old girlfriends that is amazing in its intensity. It will leave you breathless. And speaking of being breathless, let's get to what you really want to read about: the sex scenes. There were a lot more than there were in the first movie, and they were way more graphic, but let's not get carried away. The sexual scenes were filmed with artistry and integrity, and are nothing anyone should be offended by. There were some mild BDSM elements, but it was nothing too crazy, and that brings me to another point. I'm sure you've heard people talk about how the film, and especially the book, doesn't promote a safe BDSM relationship. I've never read the book, so I can't comment on that, but having seen the movie, I can tell you that that's the point. It's not supposed to show you what a safe BDSM relationship looks like, quite the opposite. Christian even says that he's not a dominator, but a sadist. In this film Christian changes. He wants to set his sadistic tendencies aside for Anastasia, because he loves her, because he realizes true love is better than just satisfying his base sexual impulses. It's called character development, and it worked. I can't help but think that people who complained about this didn't watch the second movie or read the second book. Now granted, maybe the book is different, but the film shows a changed, a more complex, and a more complicated Christian Grey.What can I say? I liked the movie. It's not perfect, it has it's fair share of flaws (that I can't write about because of the 1,000 word limit!), but "Fifty Shades Darker" is a well filmed and well acted little romance. It has sweetness and charm, and real chemistry between its lead actors. It has scrumptious set and costume design (I mean, Anastasia in that silver dress? Swoon). The ending? Adorable. The cliffhanger? Handled perfectly. The after credits scene? Now I can't wait for the final entry in this trilogy. You've heard the hate, you've heard the controversy, and you've heard the criticism. It's time to make up your own mind. "Fifty Shades Darker" may not be the best movie of 2017, but if you like romance, drama, complex characters, and suspense, then it's definitely one you should pay to see. Don't let the hate bandwagon stop you from seeing an enjoyable movie.

This might be a spoiler...but I thought the "silver balls" scene was priceless! And for all the haters who said that Dakota Johnson can't act, her facial expressions made the scene.I do have one little regret. I was really looking forward to seeing Hugh Dancy playing the part of Christian's psych. I know the movie is already 2-1/2 hours long, but if they would have just added the 10 minute segment from the book "Grey" where Flynn put everything in perspective for Christian, it would have made sense of his drastic turnaround. Maybe help out all those grumpy old men who didn't like the movie?If you liked the books, you'll like the movie...much better than the first! Can't wait for Freed!

reviews.review_title: Way better than the first one.
reviews.content:
To be honest, I thought the first one was rushed and not that good and made me put off watching the other two when they came out, but I just saw this one on Netflix and I gotta say it was a pleasant surprise. I really enjoyed it.
Sure, his one had some rushed scenes too, but overall a good movie.
And the cinematography is gorgeous.
Yeah, two thumbs up.

I have seen bad movies lately, but Fifty Shades Darker would be on the top of my list. Despite the meaningless story, nothing is properly done, from acting, to production and direction... it is very cheap by all meaning. There are movies that have bad scripts but nice costumes, bad actors but great lines, bad cinematography but great leading actors, bad lines but great cinematography. Those movies are bad but worth watching. This film is just bad. And not just bad, but worthless. I am sure that many people cared enough to express their disappointment, And the funny thing, they expect to go with another episode, from what the end tells...

There is nothing healthy or safe about this story.This isn't BDSM. These stories are a rape fantasy.It is mindless portrayal of dangerous things with no thought about reality.
This is only fantasy about a fantasy from an author who knows less than nothing about how these dynamic relationships.Not respecting boundaries makes this story about rape and not BDSM.There is nothing of value in this series.

Fifty Shades Darker is the second film the Fifty Shades Trilogy and it did not disappoint! I have read the first two books and saw the first movie, which I really liked. This movie is even better than the first. Unlike the first film, this one really had a deeper story and more character development. Christian and Ana get back together after breaking up in the first film and rekindle their love for each other, but this time no rules or punishments! I thought this was a great movie and I really enjoyed watching it. There were a few good parts in the book that were left out, but wasn't a big deal in the end. I thought the movie kept up with the book very well and is a must see for Fifty Shades fans!

I think it's a pretty good film, no need for hating it! Either watch it because of the "original" story and leave your judgmental thoughts in a separate room or don't bother watching it at all. It's a well know fact that if you've read the books you'll probably not like the films as much, and I assume that's why people are hating on it, it more exciting to create the imaginary world inside your head whilst reading it, the film does all the job for you, so that's another reason to not watch it if you know you're one of those people. I really like storytelling and I believe there are so many ways to tell a story and I'm okay with both the book and the film. I myself prefer a lot of details and background to the story and characters and that's never rarely ever given to you in a film (that's the part where you have to make it up yourself, or read the book first to get it), and I get that, because if they would, people would think it's slow and boring. I think this was a lot better than the first film, acting wise. I really have to give Jamie Dornan credit, I didn't like his acting in the first film but he really stepped up his game, maybe he got to know the cast and crew better so that he could relax a bit more. Which I could find very relatable if that's the case. or he just really found answers to the missing questions. I really liked it!

This one... The problem is they portray men as weak unless they are constantly having sex, and women are weak if they're not always bending to their partner's every will. They say BDSM should always be flaunted and proud of. It's also offensive to rape victims. You know how abuse and rape should be treated with care and respect? Well, this messes that up. It basically says that if you walk in on your parents having sex, you've been raped and scarred for life. That is stupid. So because this guy walked in on his parents having sex, he has to abuse his girlfriend in order to get it up? I mean, who needs a loving, caring, stable, healthy relationship when you can have glorified rape? The soundtrack is terrible, the acting is terrible, the whole "Masquerade Ball" thing reminds me of gross underground human trafficking dungeons, the messages are terrible, the characters are terrible, and the fact that this started as a Twilight fan fiction is kind of speaking for it's quality. And the worst thing is, this setup would have worked if it was a horror movie. But this is a romance that glorifies rape and pokes fun at actual rape victims. It says that the ideal man is a straight, rich, white guy who abuses his girlfriend. Do not watch this. Watch Lego Batman, Beauty and the Beast, Kong: Skull Island, paint dry, anything is better.

reviews.review_title: One of the worst movies i've seen in my life
reviews.content: Where to start let's talk about the acting is bad nobody gave a good performance and Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dorian have no chemistry in this excuse of a movieStory is uninteresting and boring you don't give a sh@t about the characters or nothing.Characters this characters are boring,uninteresting and fake nobody felt real or convincing this character are really hate able they could die and you wouldn't care less about them.Verdict 0/10 ONE OF THE WORST MOVIES I'VE SEEN IN MY ENTIRE LIFE. Don't ever try to see it is not a guilty pleasure is not a fun you are drunk is so bad you would want to die
Again! Brilliantly told... more of a story for these characters to tell.. great chemistry made me root for them so badly!!

reviews.review_title: One of the Worst Movies of the Year
reviews.content: Unlike most people, I actually found the first Fifty Shades movie, "Fifty Shades of Grey," enjoyable in a "it's so bad that it's good" kinda way and honestly I was hoping for more of the same. Unfortunately, what we actually get is a long overly melodramatic mess. The biggest offense of the film is the writing. It feels as if the book was used in place of a script. So almost every mundane and useless moment is kept in. And us as the audience suffer because we have to sit through a longer run time with not much happening. Also for a movie that marketed itself on being sexy and taboo, it's quite mild. The most intense they get is a couple of spank scenes that ultimately end in missionary and a cut away to them naked in bed. Because of the terrible writing in the film, the actors don't have much to work with and as a result they give embarrassingly bad performances. Their line delivery feels unnatural and awkward because literally no one talks like that in real life and I feel like the actors realized it, but went along for a fat paycheck. The soundtrack and style isn't bad, but with so much nonsense going on around, they do nothing to make the experience enjoyable, instead I was thinking about which songs I can add to my playlist. In short, "Fifty Shades Darker" is a long drawn out melodramatic soap opera that managed to become a feature length film that takes itself too seriously. It has nothing of substance and you can actually find sexier things on television. I give it 2/5

reviews.review_title: Loved it for what it was.
reviews.content: Have some Margartitas and go to see the movie. Loved it! It felt more natural this time around . I really like the actors they did a good job. Great movie to see with girlfriends . Read the books first then you will appreciate the movies better. The second book was my fave so I was really looking forward to this movie. It's funny when people rate the movie so low. What were you thinking it was going to be?? Get a grip people . Kim Basinger is in which was a little weird that they picked her to play Eleina. I wondered what Jamie's wife thought watching that movie? He is very good looking.. Anastasias hair was much better I thought this movie, not so stringy.

reviews.review_title: IT WAS BETTER. Be more open-minded. Stop being so harsh!
reviews.content: I can't believe I am writing a review, but after I read the books, I was very disappointed by the first movie. It had nothing. But the SECOND MOVIE was BETTER. However, if most of you keep rating it at 1 means that you cannot accept that something bad can become good. I went to the movie and I said to myself that everyone is laughing/ criticizing/ hating it because they all expect a masterpiece of whatever they believe it should be, but do not think for one second that the movie is mainly how the book is. Books are not complex and the adventurous part is kinda missing. Thus, THIS MOVIE, tried to make the best of it, with some errors, though. 1. It did create emotion and it was sexy. Ana was sexy!Christian was OK. Also, they cannot focus much on his character because the books are always about Ana, Ana, Ana... 2. It was funny, some stupid dialogues which could have been replaced or shortened, but it also had scenes that made you smile and see that they tried to do better. 3. There is vanilla sex in this part of the movies because this is how the book is. The kinky/dark part was in the 1st book, which, as we know, the movie failed to bring it. 4. Stop being so harsh! This is it. If you have better suggestions maybe you could state what you wanted, instead of repeating how shitty it was.And I am not a big fan of Fifty Shades and I would not write this if I didn't feel like it deserves it. This was a normal movie, not bad, not wow, but yeah, it was worth seeing it! And it deserves a chance and an open-mind!

reviews.review_title: Such a shame! Feels like the movie is very loosely based on the books.
reviews.content: The author and her husband should have let competent and passionate directors and screenwriters do their job because pictures are different than a written story. The books were fine; a decent captivating first person point of view about a gentle feminine character who finds reciprocated love and connection to someone unexpected. None of that translates into the movie. NONE. The female lead comes off as harsh. The binding love is non existent. The current between them, the sensual and carnal love is completely missing. Feels like the movie is only loosely based on the books. To top it all, the things the male lead says and does are simply not in line with his screen character either. He comes off weak, and pathetic, despite Jamie Dornan's attempts to save the day. The movie as it is makes it look like the actors can't act. I bet they were in stitches during shooting. Erika Leonard the author of the books made a 1500 pages long point about the power of connection between two person. She calls it an electrifying current that is in a constant flow between them. Everything else stems from there. They cannot resist one another. They are a slave of this love, cannot get enough of each other, they adore each other. Why is this lost in the screenplay? The screen characters are just lame. Didn't Mr Leonard get the books? Where is the unbearable pain, with the constantly flowing tears brought on by the profound grief of loosing such a love? There is a confusion about the red room too. It should be pretty clear that throughout their relationship its use and meaning transfers as in: "We aim to please" for the man. And comes in play in terms of pleasure for the girl propelled by their trusting and overwhelming love for each other. The books are such a success because they portray the binding and transforming power of love, the palpable connection, the never enough pleasing each other, the overwhelming loveliness of each others company! The characters really do care about each other. It is something we all yearn for, appreciate and celebrate, gives meaning to life. Unfortunately it's all lost in the screenplay. FSD gives out mixed messages, dangerous even.There is a profound problem with almost every scene in the movie. Cudos to Bella Heathcote, she was good. Beside money making there should be responsibility in putting novels to screen!

reviews.review_title: People who rate bad misses the point
reviews.content: I love this movie serie. I have watched them all and also read the books. The movies is so much better without the many detailed sex scenes. What is best With the movie serie is about the story of Christian Grey. Why he is a sadist, How Ana makes him a better person, able to feel love and enjoy life. I love the chemistry between the caracters, even though the chemistry between the actors could be better. I have seen it many Times, just for the feeling of this complicated relationship

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the first part
reviews.content: Not as good as the first part, since some of the book is missing or has been changed. Especially the story about Dr. Flynn is completely absent. The actors are great again in their roles and the character changes and development of the characters can be felt. The soundtrack is also brilliant. Unfortunately, the Christian-Sub scene was messed up, which would have needed a better script. And the change in Mia's appearance doesn't fit either, because it looks completely different in the book.
They should implement a negative scale. Movies like this deserve it.

reviews.review_title: Hits the target demo, but not for everyone
reviews.content: Got a chance to see it in a screening last night, and I will admit I am not the target demo for this movie but my wife really wanted to see it. It's far better than the first. More story lines make it a better movie but I kind of found that these weren't used in the best way. Plot kind of seemed incidental, but I have been told that the books were the same way so I guess it is faithful to the material. In no way did I find this movie to be sexist as previous reviews have stated. Lots of graphic sex scenes, but that should be expected. If you loved the books, you will love the film and your husband may not be as bored as with the first one.

Full disclosure, I didn't think the first movie was as bad as it was made out to be. It wasn't good in almost any sense, but it was to be expected given the combination of source material, resources and constraints.That said, this sequel is 20x better than the first. Having established the characters in the first movie, the actors seem to be able to act now comfortably in their parts. The story becomes much more nuanced with plenty of dynamics on the go.SPOILERS from now onCan they maintain a "vanilla" relationship? Is he going to become controlling again and ruin things? Will she let it get out of control and ruin things also or stay on it? Who is that stalky girl and what happened to her exactly? what about his mother? and that ex of his? Will something occur with her infatuated boss?On top of all of this, I realised while watching that the series was never about a bizarre sadist control freak, it's actually about all men and the story of a woman trying to find the balance between accepting or desiring the dominant behaviour of the male archetype and maintaining strength and independence in such a relationship.While of course the fact that he is rich, while possibly relating to the power struggle, looks like it is going to be more and more used for generating further drama. The romance is much more evident in this movie to/

In the leading up to the release of this movie for the first time in cinema, I worried that it wouldn't be as good as the first one which I thoroughly enjoyed and, sadly, watch on repeat occasionally. When I finally came round to watching it however, it lived up to my expectations and indeed beyond. I feel that in this movie the characters have a lot more personality, living up to their characters. I find the way that the actors portray the characters to be perfect and they really get across who and what the characters are meant to be, bringing out the emotion in all the scenes of the movie. When watching this movie the characters made me laugh, cry and somewhat aroused... The plot itself is also very similar to the book despite the occasional changes here and there. As for the more intense scenes...they definitely get across the mood that's for sure and are done well. All in all I think that this movie definitely lives up to expectations in my personal opinion and moves the movies closer to the finale that I now cannot wait for!

It is the best movie for people accidentaly born without a brain. Lucky for them that there is nothing in F S o G to think about it.Yesterday I watched a nameless documentary movie about some... animals on NatGeo. You know what? That was like 500% more interesting.Only God know how this story was a best-seller once... seems like zombie apocalyps is more and more closer.

This film by far excelled the captivation of love and hunger for the need of the one you love, far further beyond what the first film did, "Fifty Shades of Grey". This is a huge credit to the change of director I feel. It created a much stronger engagement in all scenes of the film, not just the sex. Congratulations to the director, it really is a great film that I thoroughly enjoyed watching. Please direct the next instalment. :) It was touching to see how the characters really open up, and you feel their frustration, especially Ana. The camera close ups were very much one in which you can't look away. Put it this way, halfway through the film I needed to go to the toilet but I held it cause I wasn't going to miss one second of the film. I would advise anyone that wants to read the book before the film , not to. It will be truly FAR more satisfying to read the book after the film. The details are deeper that way, but if you read it before the film you won't enjoy it as much :)

I enjoyed this movie. I know this is not high brow movie fair. This is simply a good time movie. You either enjoy the story (or to some lack thereof) or you don't. But to me this movie was a good (guilty) pleasure. The acting, story and the directing was good. This movie and the next one after it, didn't take it self as seriously as the first one did, I was not a fan of the first one. The last two were good though.

The first film, based on the awful racy novel by E.L. James, was released on Valentine's Day and became a massive success, despite it being rather naff, including Razzie wins, the adaptation of the trilogy of books continued with this sequel, from Razzie nominated director James Foley (Glengarry Glen Ross, House of Cards). Basically it has been some time since young corporate executive Christian Grey (The Fall's Razzie nominated Jamie Dornan) and Anastasia "Ana" Steele (Razzie nominated Dakota Johnson) broke up, Ana is now working as an assistant to Jack Hyde (Eric Johnson), an editor at Seattle Independent Publishing, who has more than a casual interest in Ana. Ana attends the evening of the art gallery show for her photographer friend Jose Rodriguez (Victor Rasuk), she is shocked Christian is there, she reluctantly agrees to have dinner with him. Christian tells Ana he wants her back, but she is reluctant because his sexual pleasure in inflicting pain and sticking to his contract, he insists he is changing, and will agree to Ana's terms of no rules and no punishments, if they will resume their relationship, she agrees. A few days later, Ana is interrupted by a woman who bears a striking resemblance to her, she later goes to dinner with Jack, Christian sees him flirting with Ana, he warns her of Jack's obvious intentions, and tells her that he plans to take over SIP where Ana works. While out with Christian for breakfast, Ana sees the same woman watching from a distance, Christian does not answer Ana immediately when she asks who she is, at home he reveals it is Leila Williams (Bella Heathcote), one of his former submissives. Christian explains that after Leila's contract ended, she wanted more to their relationship, but he did not, she found herself a husband, but he died, this caused her to have a mental breakdown and become suicidal, she has been stalking Christian and Ana for a while. Christian invites Ana to a masquerade ball with an auction, to prepare for the ball Christian takes Ana to beauty salon Esclava, there Ana sees Elena Lincoln (Razzie winning Kim Basinger), Christian's former dominant who introduced him to the BDSM lifestyle, Ana is furious Christian would take her there, and that he co-owns the salon with Elena. At the ball, Ana learns more about Christian, including being expelled from schools for fighting, and his biological mother being a prostitute and crack addict, Christian reveals his mother committed suicide, Grace Trevelyan Grey (Marcia Gay Harden) cared for him in hospital, and later adopted him. Elena confronts Ana, telling her to break up with Christian and warning her, Ana ignores her and tells her to stop meddling in their relationship, returning home Christian and Ana find her car vandalised. A few days later, when the SIP offices close, Jack tries to seduce Ana, she refuses and escapes, Christian finds out and arranges for Jack to be dismissed, he also asks Ana to move in with him, she agrees, the next day Ana takes the vacant position of temporary acting editor for SIP. Ana and Christian go to her apartment to collect her belongings, there Leila appears and threatens Ana with a gun, she fires a shot into the wall, but Leila is subdued by Christian and his bodyguard Jason Taylor (Max Martini). Ana sees that Christian can still only be satisfied with his controlling and domination, she walks out and does not return until the night, Christian is furious with her, Ana explains she needs time. Christian does not want to lose Ana, he drops to his knees and turns submissive, finally allowing her to touch him in his restricted areas, they kiss and have sex. during the night, after being awoken by Ana from a nightmare, Christian asks Ana to marry him, she says she needs time to think about it. Christian leaves for a few days on a business trip, while piloting his helicopter there is engine failure, causing it to crash somewhere in the forest, the news breaks out that Christian is missing, Ana and Christian's family wait for news, until he unexpectedly arrives, Ana is overwhelmed he is safe, realising the extent of her feelings for Christian, she accepts his marriage proposal. At Christian's birthday party, the engagement is announced to the guests, Elena is there and furious, calling Ana a gold digger, Ana angrily throws a drink in her face and tells her to stop interfering, Christian and ? Grace overhear, Christian tells Elena she only taught him sex, never love, Grace slaps Elena and tells her to get out, Christian cuts all ties with Elena. In the end, as the birthday festivities begin, Christian proposes to Ana at the boathouse, with a ring, she accepts, as fireworks erupt in the sky, Jack is the watching Ana and Christian from afar. Also starring Luke Grimes as Elliot Grey, Eloise Mumford as Kate Kavanagh and singer Rita Ora as Mia Grey. Johnson is only slightly less naive as the besotted and feisty young woman, and Dornan is still a pervy billionaire, only slightly less controlling, they are more believable as a couple this time, and Basinger and Eric Johnson are only relatively alright being the nasty ones.
