I am relieved to say that I found this film much more bearable than the previous, the change of director helps, the writing is slightly improved, there are more softcore sex scenes that are a little more comfortable than before, and the kinky and edgy bits are a little less embarrassing, it remains glossy and somewhat gigglesome in its approach, but overall it is a slightly better erotic romantic drama. It won the Razzie for Worst Remake, Rip-Off or Sequel, and it was nominated for Worst Picture, Worst Screen Combo for Any Combination of Two Characters, Two Sex Toys or Two Sexual Positions and Worst Screenplay. Worth watching!

I would definitely recommend this movie. If you're a fan of E.L James' fifty shades of grey then you'll love this!The thrill and excitement in this movie is never-ending. Christian (Jamie Dornan) finally realized that he could not let Anastasia (Dekota Johnson) go. He fought for her with Jack Hyde (Eric Johnson) and Elena (Kim Basinger).This movie is more focused on Christians past and what turned him into the person he is, he opens up to Anastasia slowly but surly and lets her touch his scared body.Christian wakes up due to a nightmare in one wholesome scene and Anastasia attends to him with comfort, this kind of made him realize how much of an impact Ana has on him AND his life, so he asks her to marry him!This movie definitely has its wholesome moments unlike the first move (fifty shades of grey)

reviews.review_title: A great example of constructive communication in couples
reviews.content: This movie is a great example of constructive communication in cupples, especially in approaching and tackling problems and childhood traumas. Anastasia exemplifies a strong woman partner, curious, deep thinker, with a holistic view toward relationship and great respect toward her needs, but also of her partner.

reviews.review_title: I you are here to view the review of the movie too watch it ignore the bad lazy people review.
reviews.content:
What i really liked about the movie that it made me happy.
Not like others which made me cry and then laugh.
I simply can't understand what is wrong with other people.
Peope who are comming to see the review before watching it , it is my request to ignore the others reviews. When watch it with patience you will love it.

I have reviewed several times the film: there are at least three times in the book that had to be absolutely highlighted because they are full of pathos and give meaning to the whole story, but in the film were just mentioned and made superficially banal, while the second book is the key to everything.Bad screenplay, trite and gaunt (it seems that the author has read only a summary of the book ...), bad also cinematography and directing. The entire film seems a ugly trailer. The music is only a distant echo of that of the first film. Christian appears sloppy, inconsistent, lacking in personality. Ana has no personality, but what can you with a screenplay like this ...It seems that both the director and screenwriter have never read the books and that the author, so meticulous and careful in monitoring implementation of the first film, she went, for the second, on vacation somewhere.A special, not relevant but significant (and is indicative of a total lack of care with which it was carried throughout the film and liquidated in a hurry) is the adopted brother of Christian, Elliot that in the first film was fun and bright, in FSD chewing gum throughout the film: horrible.In Fifty Shades of Gray, Sam Taylor-Johnson had hit the mark and photography of Seamus McGarvey had made magic every detail. Everything had a very refined taste and was totally devoid of vulgarity. The excitement of the first film remain only a beautiful memory: I'm really very disappointed.

extremely disappointed. for a 2 hour movie, they seemed to have squished every possible plot line they could in without tying the loose ends together. they may do in the third film, but most of them made little sense and had almost no relevance to the overall story. to expand on this, what was the point of having Christian involved in a helicopter accident? i understand that if he had of died or suffered an extreme injury such as brain damage, that would have affected the plot line greatly and would have been somewhat intriguing to see how his relationship with Ana continued with such a disadvantage, or didn't continue at all. however, he came out of it with nothing but a few scratches, had Anastasia and his family worried sick, and that was that. completely unnecessary, and if you ask me, they could have spent more time strengthening and deepening Christian and Ana's emotional relationship instead, revealing more of Christian's inner demons and how Ana is slowly teaching him how to love instead of dominate. i thought that plot line was interesting and one that definitely could have done with more attention. it was brushed over once or twice with the lipstick and shower scene, and again, that was that.another plot line that seemed a little messy to me was how Anastasia was being stalked by one of Christian's past submissive's due to jealousy. she held a gun to her, interrogated her almost, when Christian stepped in to protect Ana. he informed Ana the girl wasn't important, that he was finished with that chapter of his life, and alas, that was that. we never really learned more about the young girl's history personally or with Christian, or why she cared so much about stalking and hurting Ana. that could have been an interesting plot line if it was continued or even ended properly rather than quickly.moving on to Anastasia's creepy boss. where was this plot line leading to? or was it a sort of filler plot to show viewers the lengths Christian would go to keep Ana safe? i'm unsure, but overall, it seemed like a slight waste of time. when the boss was introduced first, the way he looked at Ana suggested he was interested in her on a deeper level than just boss to employee, which did spark a curiosity within me to see where it would lead. it began with him quite frustratingly telling her to book a hotel room to join him in new York on some business expedition, but it was quite obvious as to why he wanted to get her there alone. it ended not long after when Ana told him she couldn't go, and he pinned her to the door and forcefully told her how much better being with him (sexually) rather than Christian would be. of course, Christian was waiting for Ana just outside, so she runs into his arms and that's that. kind of pointless? as a plot line, they could have expanded on the boss personally; why was he like that (background wise), why did he want an unavailable woman who was his colleague, knowing she was with one of the most powerful businessmen? they could have had him and Ana interact more to give the audience glimpses of his intentions bit by bit instead of him all of a sudden trapping her against a door. it was all a bit quick and could have been focused on more, if not at all.i didn't mind the plot line involving Christian's past dominant, his mother's friend. however, i do think her obsession with Anastasia was a little overboard. i mean, destroying her car just to let her know she's not the one for Christian?this sounds petty, but i'm not too sure about the choice of names. i love Anastasia, but then having her assistant/co-worker be named Hannah? Ana and Hannah - it just sounded off when they would talk to each other. i'm also not sure of this character but i think she was one of Ana's bosses and had black hair. and then when we came across Christian's mother, these two characters looked almost identical and it was fair to say i was confused for a bit. last but not least, the marriage proposal! WHAT! how so soon? at the beginning they had only just got back together after Christian had done unmentionable, sadistic things to Anastasia. and even then, Anastasia had said she wanted to take things slow, which of course failed. and by the end of the film they're engaged? it's probably just because it's a film and things need to move fast, but i was quite shocked. i thought a plot line as big as this could have been focused on more in the third film, if there is one, after they had been together longer and experienced more hurdles as a steady couple.overall, this movie was quite horrible and didn't really do the book justice! it was messy and just a bit 'all over the place'. if they do end up making a third movie, i sincerely hope for the sake of EL James that the story is portrayed and tied up nicely!

Dakota Johnson and Jamie Dornan reprise their roles as Ms. Steele and Christian Grey, respectively, in "Fifty Shades Darker." After being freaked out by Dornan's sadist ways in "Fifty Shades Of Grey," Johnson quickly gets back together with Dornan after setting up a "no rules, no punishment" alteration to their original relationship. Things seem to go well until a weird, disheveled chick starts appearing intermittently to freak out Johnson; sexual harasser/creepy boss named Jack Hyde (dude, seriously, this is a name that I would come up with back when I was 14-years-old writing short stories, so it kind of gives you a hint as to the writing talents of the screenwriter and/or author of the books) comes on strong to Johnson, which freaks her out; and "Mrs. Robinson" is revealed, giving Johnson advice about she's not good enough for Dornan and she needs to leave him, which freaks out Johnson.So with all this stuff going on — and handled badly by the screenwriter/director/editor — what is the spine, or theme of this movie? If I had to guess, it's Johnson and Dornan trying to change for each other, trying to find a compromise so that they can continue their relationship. That's all good and well; but "Fifty Shades Darker" is less focused and more comedic (not deliberately, I bet) than the first movie, and the first movie was no masterpiece. I know that most sequels tend to be of a less quality than their predecessors, but in the case of "Fifty Shades Darker," the difference in quality is really jarring. It felt as if there were 10 drafts of the movie, and instead of the 10th, polished draft being produced, the 3rd draft got produced. Moving on My most memorable, movie moment of "FSD" is the scene when **SPOILER ALERT** Dornan tells a creepy, former submissive who is flipping out to "kneel," and she does so instantaneously. This is probably the best written scene of the movie, as it shows Dornan's immense power over his former subs; Dornan's possible, continued need for that kind of pure obedience; and Johnson's full realization that she can never give that to Dornan.Bottom line, for those who didn't understand nor liked the first movie, you'll definitely hate this one. But for those who were entertained by the first movie, as I was, you'll probably want to see "FSD" because you want to see how things turn out, despite the cheesy, corny, ridiculous events and dialogue. Look, it's like a two hour soap opera, and if treated as such, and you are the type to get entertained by soap operas and soft core porn, then "Fifty Shades Darker" may be a decent piece of entertainment for a couple of hours. Of course, if watched with a significant other, the entertainment value of this movie goes up significantly (insert winky face here).Mannysmemorablemoviemoments

Hunky squillionaire Christian Grey likes to strap up girlfriends and spank them until their bums go red. Having relieved incredibly nice improbable virgin Anastasia of her virginity in a dead romantic and non-pervy fashion, she subsequently reacts badly to having her bum whacked, and terminates their relationship. And that's where this film begins.And, while it has the odd bit of fetish activity in it, it mostly amounts to a conventional romantic drama peppered with the problems which rich and mildly sexually perverted people tend to encounter, like exes turning up with guns, malicious Mrs Robinson-types seeking to stick a spoke into your current relationship, crashing your helicopter on Mount St Helens, and the like.Jamie Dornan and Dakota Johnson are likeable and have some chemistry together. That chemistry isn't particularly sexual: for a film drawn from a source which is notorious for the appeal of its sexual fetish content, this film is sparse and coy in that regard. It is also singularly unerotic notwithstanding the fact that both Dornan and Johnson look attractive without clothes. No, I'm not being entirely truthful - there is a short sequence in a lift which is more erotic than all the naughty bits in this film and its predecessor put together.I confess that, while I normally quite enjoy watching attractive young people engaging in sexual activity, the specifics of Christian Grey's proclivities are pretty much the antithesis of what turns me on. Having said that, I repeat that there is relatively little of that stuff here, and it's not valid grounds for criticising a film anyway.Better grounds for criticism are that, despite the best efforts of the actors, the characters are fundamentally unconvincing, as are the glitches in their relationship and, indeed, the other problems they face. The sole interesting issue from the first film - should two incompatible people seek to change each other fundamentally? - is here avoided because that is simply what happens, with no agonising, soulsearching, or explanation. What is left is glossy soap opera with mild perversion.The film is basically a shambles, and I offer no speculation as to whether this is the fault of the source novel, or the screenplay (written by the novelist's husband).I am sure that the white middle-class women who bought the books by the lorryload, and went to see episode one in droves, will be along to see this one, too. They may well be disappointed, because I couldn't detect much by way of forbidden frisson.And for anyone not in the target demographic, I can't honestly recommend this. In fact, I rather feel that I went to see this so that you don't have to. How very public-spirited of me. You can thank me by not going to see it unless you are dragged along by the missus.

I don't know what I was expecting, except the worse, which is actually what I received.I knew going in I wasn't going to hear dialogue that was better than the last film or see acting that was done with an iota of talent or conviction and I was right. The dialogue is, if anything, worse. I didn't think that was possible, but I should have realised that is the author's husband is the writer of the screenplay then of course it would be as bad as in the book, well worse than that.The acting was worse than the first one. No emotion from any of the actors. The portrayal of abusive relationships in the first film were bad enough but here it has been jacked up to unbelievable levels.

reviews.review_title: '...generally, a key part of good communication is that both parties be conscious.'
reviews.content:
As is often the case with sequels (or parts 2, 3 and on) the initial impact of Part One (a fairly substantial examination of the dominant/submissive relationship complete with toys and lots of nudity and intercourse) overshadows the subsequent stories. So it happens with FIFTY SHADES DARKER (or DULLER). New screenwriter this time round (Niall Leonard) adapting EL James infamous Chick Lit and a male director this time - James Foley. Not as strong a team as Round One. But then there are may little things that dim the lights on this outing - less sincere chemistry between the lead couple, too much meandering in wealthy parties, an unshaven Christian Grey (just to keep up with the styles) and the addition of some unsavory characters who attempt to add tension but without enough back story to make it work.The plot - Christian (Jamie Dornan) and Ana (Dakota Johnson) decide to rekindle their relationship, except this time there are no more rules or punishments. As they begin to get used to their newfound relationship, Christian's past (fifteen prior women, childhood abuse, a nasty sordid affair (Bella Heathcote) and the threat of a strange woman (Kim Basinger) begins to haunt Ana as Christian struggles with his innermost thoughts. There is competition for Ana from her new boss (Eric Johnson) that provides a cliffhanger at the end of this far too long film.
Gone is the novelty of the Red Room and sadism and life seems to be settling into ho-hum. Maybe things will pick up in the third installment...Grady Harp, March 18

reviews.review_title: Nothing to do with the first movie
reviews.content: What is this?? The acting was terrible and like... their faces look sad... honestly I didn't like it at all... I haven't read the book but I bet is nothing like this :/ Honestly... Disappointing... I won't reveal anything but oh man... I have a coworker that she went to watch it 3 times, I'll ask her what she saw on this because it was awful, I waste of time... I was expecting way more.

reviews.review_title: Why is everyone acting like this film is awful?
reviews.content: Okay!! we get it, the fifty shades series isn't the most groundbreaking films to ever be made, but why is everyone being SO hard on it, its not that bad, honestly its not. I watched this film on valentines day, (even my boyfriend didn't hate it) overall everyone in the cinema seemed pretty happy with the film. The film picks up from where the first film was left, the film sticks pretty close to the novel which was nice to see. this film for me was an improvement on the first one, probably down to the fact James Foley directed this one, once again the cinematography was absolutely beautiful, i take my hat off to John Schwartzman. The soundtrack to both of this films so far have been excellent and fitted in with the plot perfectly. the on screen chemistry between the two main characters Christian and Ana i feel is better in the second one, the film starts with Christian trying to fix his mistakes and goes on to Ana dealing with issues from his past. We get to know the characters a lot more in this film as Christian opens up more to Ana and shows his vulnerable side. and the DRAMA follows. okay here it is.. the sex scenes... are... better? i thought they were less awkward in this film, and sexier, Dakota seems to be more comfortable on screen with the nudity now which makes the scenes a lot easier to watch. overall this film is well made, funny, dramatic and romantic. 6.5/10Forget everything you have heard about this film and watch it with an open mind, who knows, you might even like it.

reviews.review_title: Shallow but good looking and watchable guilty pleasure
reviews.content: Greetings from Lithuania.The most funny thing about "Fifty Shades Darker" (2017) is that it is a very watchable, good looking movie while in at the same time it is very shallow, woodenly acted and kinda poorly written movie. The only good acting in this highly manipulative story was by Dakota Johnson - she carried the movie. And while this is kinda of a romantic movie, there was zero chemistry between the two lead, although like i said i liked acting by Dakota Johnson - the lead guy was no match for her. And the whole sex scenes were just boring - the most boring this in the movie.That said, strangely enough i did enjoy "Fifty Shades Darker" while i was watching it. You kinda have to turn your brain off while watching this movie and it does work as a guilty pleasure on a boring evening. All in all this is definitely not bad movie to see it once but after you will forget it pretty soon.

reviews.review_title: Are you kidding me? 'Fifty Shades Darker' was awesome!
reviews.content: I just came back from the theater, after read some really bad comments from some people i just had to check and see what was all the hype about (negative publicity = publicity). Boy oh boy did i enjoy it? It was funny, sexy, melodramatic, entertaining and exciting! I'm not saying that the movie was perfect but for what it was - it was great i say Dakota in the movie "A Bigger Splash" so i already knew that she is a very charming actress. The guy who played Grey did a wonderful job as well.. Both of them are very charming and charismatic people. Give the movie a chance, stop with all the hate and don't let your ego control yourself. FSD - 10 out of 10!

I liked the first trilogy. That being said, this wasn't as good as its predecessor. It lost the feminine touches from a female director and female script writer. Also gone are the artistic cinematography, well lit set and breathtaking Seattle/Vancouver landscape. Erotic scenes felt blunt and impassionate unlike the first trilogy where they were wittier and more fervent. Story makes no sense, it felt rushed and lacked of any development and depth. As someone who had not read the book, I expected a rewrite that accommodates a broader audience but instead they made an exact adaption from the book for the fans. I understand the fascination from the fans but for the others, we got lost into small plots that were not even logical. And missed opportunities on not focusing more into Grey's inner world and his relationship with the other female villains!

needs improving. I don't get why they can't get better scripts and better acting for movies about such famous books. But still I think this sequel was a little better than the first film, which rarely happens. I just thought the story was a little better and not so silly. One part that I didn't like was how the helicopter crash was never explained, how did the copter not burst into flames. Can't stand plot holes like that. And the petty Elena character was written so silly, why would she care about Ana?FINAL VERDICT: OK, but still probably only for fans of the books.

This movie was fantastic, I think that may even be an understatement. James Foley has upgraded everything that we were looking for in the first movie. The script comes in with great witty one liners and the amount of sex scenes that should have been originally given in the first movie. Both Dakota and Jamie bring a new side to their characters, a better side. This movie keeps with drama, romance, sex, thrills, and even comedy. It's one movie filled with a lot of genres. If you are a lover of the books, you won't be disappointed. Some people may be offended by the explicit scenes and not so "vanilla" sex. If you're comfortable with sexuality, you will very much enjoy it in its entirety. A lot of people think Ana is a weakling and Christian is a dominant, but you have to see beyond what people are commenting on. She is a confident young woman who makes sure Christian knows how she feels. The soundtrack is also fantastic and perfectly fitting. All in all. 10/10!!!

reviews.review_title: Exactly what I was hoping to see!
reviews.content: Despite the negative reviews..This IS a good movie. I actually really enjoyed watching it and I look forward to the third one. I didn't have high expectations going in due to some of the poor reviews but I left feeling satisfied and entertained. Dakota and Jamie DO have amazing chemistry despite what others have written. She is a much better written character in this story than the first and he is also much more realistic in the sense that he seems like he could actually exist (the first movie was very unrealistic to the point of laughable) I liked the dark twists in this one and they all led to an important part in the story. I.E. The helicopter scene was a bit cheesy but they needed to write that in to have Anna's character realize she can't live without him. It could've been a car crash or something a bit more realistic considering he's walking into his apartment hours later. But whatever! This is an erotica/fantasy/drama and it's made for you to escape your reality for 2 hours. These two have gorgeous bodies and amazing chemistry and the story is fun and entertaining. What more do you want from an erotica/fantasy/drama? Geez. Everyone needs to relax and let go from all the uptight expectations for this type of film. I give it 7 stars (6 for the film but I bumped it up to 7 for Jamie's bod) :) Go see it, and have some fun at the movies for once!

I am writing my first movie review because I feel that the critics do not understand the Fifty Shades phenomenon.Readers of "mommy porn" enjoy the genre because it is a fun escape into a fantasy world. I think most people who read the Fifty Shades books and watch the movies really do understand that it should not be taken seriously.And that is why I gave the movie an 8/10 stars. Jamie Dornan improves on his performance as Christian from the first movie. Dakota Johnson is still funny and brilliant as Ana.The movie delivers on all fronts with its core audience.It includes many great scenes from the book.Some parts of the book that are not included IMO were not missed.The only problem I had was that I wished a few scenes in the movie were fleshed out a little better, adding a few more lines of dialogue to explain what was happening in the scene.But my husband, who has not read the books, liked it.Go see this movie.It's worth the price of a ticket.

reviews.review_title: Well that's 117 minutes I can't get back
reviews.content:
From the bestselling author of the erotic tale this sequel is based on Anna Steele played by Dakota Johnson who has sorta moved on from Christian Grey played by Jamie Dorman. But when he re-enters her life will she go back to him for more erotic behavior?
Overall this film is bad. The acting sucks,there is too much flith in it. I would rather watch A Star Is Born or Kate and Leopold than to watch this crap. There is even this guy called Jack who Christian sorta knows and Rita Ora the UK singer is in this mediocre mess.
0/10

Nothing in this film makes any sense. WTF! The story line - trash, acting - trash, ending - trash. It's like they try to come up with a "story" to thread a few cheap sex films together. Wasted my time and insulted my intelligence. This review should be summarized in ne word - trash!!!

reviews.review_title: The books don't translate well to film
reviews.content: What's hard for me to figure out is why the books don't translate well into films. Both of these films follow the books pretty closely with the exception of changing subtle things like settings and cutting certain things. For instance when you read the book their sex is very descriptive but the sex scenes in this film last all of thirty seconds or so. I still don't find their chemistry to be all that great but better than the first film. They remind me of Robert Pattinson and Kristen Stewart in the sense that it's like well I got picked for the part and you got picked for the part too bad we're not that great together. Which while on that subject safe to say Fifty Shades is basically Twilight for adults. Anastasia or Anna is a virgin like Isabella or Bella. They both love literature and lose it to a man they marry (with one waiting til marriage). Our leading men both with formal names are dark and although appearing confident are insecure. Christian's sister Mia is basically Alice. Also in new moon a crazy chick was after them just like Darker. Edward's father is a doctor. Christian's mother is a doctor. Its almost as if E.L James read Twilight, took out vampires and werewolves, and put in lots of sex. I didn't like the fact that Jack was more evil in the movie than he was in the book. He's basically just used so there can be a third novel/film. Reading the books, however over the top they may be, has been a much better experience than seeing the films. I don't even think people who haven't read the books would like these movies that much because they don't go into as much detail. Also my biggest complaint was that they completely cut out Dr. Flynn Christian's therapist. They insinuate he'll just get better telling Anna his secrets when a big part of his recovery is therapy. Dr. Flynn is literally the one who tells Christian to try a relationship Anna's way. Lastly the soundtrack was terrible. It felt like listening to teeny bop music while watching adults have sex it was weird. Frigging Twilight had a more adult soundtrack! Anyway to sum up for the second time around the books just don't translate well into films. It's nice to stare at pretty actors with great bodies but that's pretty much all these films will ever be.

reviews.review_title: The next fifty shades between an ordinary woman and a billionaire.
reviews.content: The film was not received well as the book was. Just like the first film, it has been another below average. Might be because of its theme. Usually this kind of films do great business, but ratings and reviews does not praise or encourage the film. So I doubt anybody will be bored of it, which means watchable film and instead it won't be their favourite.The story continued and this time it was not based on experiment or any kind of agreement, but mutual understanding. So the billionaire Grey and Ana's erotic adventure sustains. With the small-small developments the film goes all the way to the ending. That means, those who are watching it for the selected scenes, will surely would have a nice time. But nothing was strong as any European film on the similar theme.Apart from the weak storyline, there's nothing wrong with it. As to what this film is about, it served better. That's what I say to you not to expect full storied romance-drama. As usual the actors were good and another two films to come in the 'Fifty Shades' franchise. I hope they can be better than the first two. Overall, it is only for the selected audience, but curiosity makes everybody watch it and they all pour they perspective which is flooded with average to negative. Otherwise, it is an acceptable film.6/10

reviews.review_title: Fifty Shades Darker is the equivalent of having sex with someone you don't want to be with.
reviews.content: By that, I mean you want the lights off so you can't see their face. So turn your lights off, and while you're up just turn the TV off as well because there is no point watching this. Granted, this is ever so slightly better than it's predecessor. But that's like saying cat litter tastes nicer than dog poo, they're both excrements. I mean where to begin with the story? Christian Grey yearns for Anastasia and becomes a creepy stalker. Will they? Won't they? Again, I don't care. Oh, and random people from his past keep popping up like an unwanted STD. Speaking of, we were graced with Mr Grey ripping off a condom in the first film, just to encourage safe sex. In this? None of that. Spreading disease at a rate of Oprah Winfrey audience members getting presents. "You get a disease! You get a disease! Everybody gets a disease!!". We have our usual accompaniment of pop songs to the raunchy sex scenes. Bending over a pool table, bed or even the floor...that's about as raunchy as it gets. I actually miss the whips...what have I become!? The sex now just seems forced as it's no longer a plot device, but isn't that the point of this franchise? The acting and chemistry between our two leads is much better and far more watchable, with less cringeworthy lines of dialogue. It's still damn atrocious, just more tolerable. The pace is horrendously sluggish! Two hours! Felt like four. So many unexplored sub-plots that amount to nothing. Rita Ora though...perfection. She genuinely seems excited to be there. No one else does, just give them their wages and be done with this series. Will I be watching this again? Nope. This is just the kind of thing I put myself through for friendship. Foolish me.

"Fifty Shades of Grey," if I remember correctly, was pretty much content in setting up various subplots and side characters without ever developing their relevance or relationships to the main couple. It ended with Anastasia running away from Christian because he went too far during sex. Within the first ten minutes of "Fifty Shades Darker," the two are back together. In other words, if you've missed the first installment, it doesn't matter much.One thing the predecessor had going for it, though, was the director Sam Taylor-Johnson, who actively worked against the laughable dialogue and uninspired plotting of the script. Together with her DP they even managed to sneak some interesting visual ideas into the thing. After a much-publicized falling-out, Taylor-Johnson has now been replaced with James Foley, and with her the last hint of subtlety has departed the franchise.Which is not to say that "Darker" is, as its title and the marketing would suggest, is a more aggressive and raunchy chapter in the trilogy, far from it. The sex scenes (that's what we're here for after all, right?) are not too far removed from what you would see in your average James Bond flick. There's maybe a higher number of sex toys on display here, and there are even some breasts and buttocks to be seen, but all in all, given the franchise's reputation, I was expecting much more out of an erotic thriller about S&M. Most of the sex scenes are even filmed in the same way (shadowy silhouettes shot from the side) and have overbearing pop music going on in the background, so it's hard to get into them all that much. The movie just seems to stop every couple minutes to show us a music video.Other than sex, the movie tries to sell itself by its thriller leanings. Throughout the movie we get glimpses of mysterious characters and hints of tension, but all of these suspenseful elements are always resolved just a few scenes later, usually by Christian appearing out of the blue. Whereas the first movie kept its subplots underdeveloped, this one is even worse. If being held at gunpoint and (later) potentially getting raped are only minor footnotes to the larger story and don't affect our protagonist for more than one or two scenes, why should we care about anything anymore in this story?I guess it's the romance the film is about. However, I rarely had so much trouble suspending my disbelief during sex scenes. You know the trope of teenagers having sex while the killer stalks them in slasher movies? The whole of "Fifty Shades Darker" felt like that. During the first 40 minutes or so, there are only three types of scenes: People warning Ana about Christian, Christian behaving like a dick towards Ana, and Christian and Ana having sex. I'm not Alfred Kinsey, but I don't think that's how sexual arousal works. Most of the relationship talk happens through text messages and their dates are even more music-video like than the sex scenes. It's very hard to get into the love story, especially since Jamie Dornan is not very charming in this role (he looks the part, though) and Dakota Johnson acts constantly intimidated, speaking in a quiet voice so as to not disturb her boyfriend. You want to tell her not to get in cars with strangers, not see her have "kinky" sex with her millionaire lover.There is indeed a thriller in this. If you replaced the pop music and the gentle Danny Elfman score with a Trent Reznor/Atticus Ross soundtrack, you'd have a less-beautiful, worse-written and woodener-acted David Fincher film about an abusive, dysfunctional relationship between an insecure weak-willed girl and a psychologically damaged rich playboy who preys on women like her. All the elements are in place, even Christian's relatives and other surrounding characters and the fact that Ana's friends only ever appear after two-thirds into the film, isolating her from real life, are in place. They just didn't wanna go there (probably because SM movies that actually break taboos aren't as easily marketable), so what we're stuck with is this mess of a movie with very little plot.I know it's a cliché to hate on these movies, but I just don't see what makes them good in any way. "Fifty Shades Darker" doesn't look exceptional, the acting is bland, the story just repeats the same three or four beats for over two hours, the music is distracting ... Nope, this isn't good.

As a person who read the books, the first film was awful to me. This second installment however, lived up to my expectations and then some. Everything from the set decor, wardrobe, soundtrack, and acting was spot on. Everything I imagined for first film. People who haven't read the books and fallen in love with these characters will just not understand. I love the fact that you get to see the relationship of Ana and Christian grow in this film. It's way more steamy and intimate and loving and that is what really did it for me in this one. They really show their love for one another in this film and you get to see a different side to the characters that you did not see in the first. The director did a great job and I can't wait to see their relationship progress in the next film.
The best one of the trilogy! Really really well-made!

Ok, my fiance loves these films (but she's worse than me when it comes to sex in movies, and I'll sit through some serious crap for it) so we went to go see it on Valentines Day.And I am going to point out the problem, and I will do it by quoting the synopsis from IMDB:"Anastasia must confront the anger and envy of the women who came before her."Yeah, that takes all of about 5 minutes of time in the film. It's the plot of the movie...and it takes about 5 minutes total. The problem is solved really quickly, in the middle of the film, and never comes up again.It's like an after thought....but it's the plot.I've seen movies based on T and A in the past that have actually more plot focus than this.But let's be honest, you are only watching it for the BDSM (which it is also light on) so I can't even give it 10 stars for that, and I am an easy grader when it comes to most movie reviews.

reviews.review_title: Turned into Soft Porn, Unintentionally? I doubt!
reviews.content:
An unworthy continuation, that blatantly relies on Nudity and Skin Show! Unfortunately whereas the first one succeeded in terms of delivering a wholesome package; this one's void in writing is conspicuous. Amateur hands behind the production is the sole reason to blame. Writing & Screenplay both are distraught, the detailings are vague.
Incapable Editing made it even worse, The direction is weaker on the front as there are so many repetitive moments that hold so much similarity in pattern; resulting exasperation. The saving grace was the characters themselves. Dakota Johnson as Anastasia Steele and Jamie Dornan as Christian Gray both took off exactly where they left. Gradual progression of their relationship is an intriguing watch, as they are relatable and likable to a certain extent.
They graced the sensuality with sincere audacity but at the same time too much of the same ruined the essence out of it. After a certain period of time, one can easily predict their love making skills. If you are directing a Luscious craft, atleast make it tempting enough. Make it unique, so the pleasurable moments would be justified in the eyes of the viewer. Passionate love is the purest thing one can imagine in an art form but when the drawn boundary gets blurry; things can soon turn into bothersome imagery which ultimately results in disastrous outcomes.

Sorry guys, let's face it we didn't read the books for the story line, but the sex...hell yeah. But must say the movie is a really big let down, not because of the sex scenes, but this time round Jamie was not Christian, unshaven and not as hot as he was in the first movie. This time the actors seemed way out of their league , Anna I was never sure about, not good looking enough compared to the book, with all the guys swooning after her. First movie OK this one huge let down....more excitement in Game of Thrones.

I don't know if what I say below is spoiler material, but just in case, I put the warnings on it.I have read and re-read the trilogy. The first movie was very nice and very close to the book. I was very excited to go watch this to see how well they translated his problems and her healing from the book to the movie. However, his problems seemed to be glossed over or not addressed. In exchange, we received several seemingly gratuitous soft porn scenes. I was disappointed. If the last book is made into a movie, I will wait for it to come out on DVD or BR or whatever and buy them all and watch them back-to-back.If you are looking to become sexually aroused in a room full of strangers, then this movie will do the trick. :-(

reviews.review_title: Another reason not to turn a bestseller into a movie!
reviews.content: Siimply the more you fall in love of the book the more you would hate this production - unless you our purely watching for the sex! Also, while watching the movie you will feel that the events are being pushed and wrapped too quickly to follow up as if the actors and the director are late for dinner !

If you read the books then you will love the film and even if you didn't read the books you will enjoy the story line! The movie did a really good job hitting most of the highlights from the book. Honestly the main reason why this franchise is such a hit is because of the love story of Christian and Ana and how they both change one another for the best. Give it a chance if you do not know anything about the story, and for Fifty Shades fans, it will exceed all expectations! The soundtrack was also really great and tied well into the scenes of the movie!! Perfect for a girls night out or a date with your significant other! Will go watch it again!

reviews.review_title: I know people don't like this movie BUT
reviews.content: I'm a big fan of the books && I think (if you watch the uncut versions) this Is a decent trilogy of movies. && Someone needs to acknowledge the fact that Rita Ora is an awesome cast as Christian's sister, Mia. I don't care what people say I highly recommend this movie.

Here's The Lowedown on "Fifty Shades Darker" (R - 2017 - US)...No rules...no punishments!!Genre: Drama/EroticMy Score: 6.1Cast=7 Acting=6 Plot=5 Ending=6 Story=5 Drama=7 Script=5 Filming=7 Romance=6 Erotic=7While Christian wrestles with his inner demons, Anastasia must confront the anger and envy of the women who came before her."Generally, a key part of good communication is that both parties be conscious." In a world where I grew up watching 9 1/2 weeks, this is pretty tame (at least Kim Basinger was in it) . I felt about the same as I did with the first film...Meh. There were a couple points where I raised my eyebrows, but ultimately I left the room once I lost interest. If you liked the first, then this would be worth watching. Now that I hear Dakota Johnson may not be in the 3rd one, I care even less about completing the trilogy.

reviews.review_title: It's bad, like we all knew it would be
reviews.content: I honestly think that anyone going through this comments hated this movie and I personally watched just because I wanted to watch a bad movie (Do you ever get that craving? Of watching something bad for the sake of making fun of it?) Anyways, I'm going to take the liberty of just saying things as they are, this may contain spoilers but does anyone really cares?This movie is terrible, not for one or two reasons, there are too many. But there is ONE, one in particular that drives me insane. Anastasia, a recently graduated literature student gets her dream job and becomes an editor after being molested by her boss. I am myself a literature major, can someone explain me how can I get such a great job opportunity, because so far things are quite the opposite. I know movies do not have to be realistic all the time, but this gets really dumb. If Anastasia was a real person, a real literature major she would hate this book. If she was really a talented editor she would think this book is garbage. It doesn't make any sense.The plot is ridiculous, we know that from the previous movie, but in this second part nothing major happens, where is the story here. Worst than that is the lack of sensuality in this film, is supposed to be about the sexual relationship between these characters, why there is no heat? Yes, the chemistry is a little better than in the original, but still not sexy at all. Dakota's performance is blank and quite annoying, especially in the sex scenes. The sex is just that, sex. Even when they are in the red room, they use gadgets and stuff but nothing crazy, nothing worthy of a BDSM title. The characters are boring and unlikable. You don't get to understand what is so cool about Anastasia to completely "change" Cristian because he does seem to be pushed into this new persona very quickly. He is a sadist (stated in his own word) however, he is able to stop being one because he is in love. That simple.I actually think that a story between a BSDM participant and a newcomer could be very interesting, but narrated in the right way. Not an obscenely rich guy falling in love with a boring girl with no personality of her own. I feel ashamed that an awful book like this became a best seller. However, I do have the hope that one day these books and movies will be remembered just as an unfortunate joke.

Most romantic movie I've ever seen, close to the book and the chemistry between Dornan and Dakota is off the charts! Loved it!! Would see it again. Liked it better than the first one because more depth to the story and characters. I like the soundtrack in the first movie better. Didn't care for the songs in this movie. Worth the two year wait, it's going to be a long year waiting for the third movie.I found the story flowed better than the first movie and the acting was better too. The scenery of British Columbia in the background was spectacular. The only flaw I saw, another than the soundtrack, was Dornans beard growth. In one scene it was heavier than the rest of the movie.

I might be wrong but I liked that when Anastasia got his boss' position and talked to her secretary, I believe she said the same (or very similar) words her real mother (Melanie Griffith) said in the great movie Working Girl.I don't expect you to fetch me coffee unless you're getting some for yourself

I think that this movie was so freaking good, a lot better than the first one!! Don't listen to people because this movie makes you really feel something, i even cried because the story is really touchable and pretty because he is prepared to change for her, you can really feel their love through the screen which makes it true to believe in some way, they're really great actors also because as i said you can feel their love and you don't ever want them to be apart! it's a lot of sex but cmon it's a sex novel what did you expect really? and the sex makes it even more intense and true. if you've read the books you won't be disappointed. You need to watch the movie and please don't listen to some people reviews because i tell you it is really really good. 10 out of 10!!

reviews.review_title: oh my gawddddd what a mess
reviews.content: wow. was this bad. I've read the books and they are pretty bad so my expectations are not high. let me sum this up for you without even spoiling it.sex 30 seconds of unexplained completely unsubstantiated drama sex 30 seconds of unexplained completely unsubstantiated drama sex 30 seconds of unexplained completely unsubstantiated drama sex 30 seconds of unexplained completely unsubstantiated drama sexthere you go. you've 'seen' it. i mean seriously, insert eye roll. and Rita Ora as the sister?? WHY? there is literally NO REASON for this casting choice at all. And lord, you think Rhianna is a bad actress (as far as pop stars trying to act) - wait until you catch Rita Ora. Not one line is delivered that sounds unscripted. It's truly tragic.and here is a ***spoiler alert** for what it's worth.scene. cute love text cute love text. OMG helicopter crash (literally for no reason at all. like you barely even understand why he and his associate are even in a helicopter). OMG Christian might be dead (this literally lasts 2.5 minutes then he walks in alive. like literally it's the most anti-climatic "i thought you were dead scene" in the history of ever. God, it's just so bad. I don't even know why I gave it 3 stars except they are hot to look at. That's about it.

To me, "Fifty Shades Darker" joins "The Two Towers" and "The Empire Strikes Back" in that category of films where the middle film in the trilogy is the best of the three. Not that the other two Fifty Shades movies are great cinema.I enjoyed this movie. Ana is all over the place in her moods. Christian is as goofy as ever. Most of the story exists just to give them a reason to have sex in a particular location. These two should be exhausted most of the time.I liked the music. I liked the sets and wardrobe. This one felt more like a fairy tale than the other two in the series.

My god people this is not a movie for the Oscars, so snap out of it! If you are not interested reading the books why go see the movie and then destroy it? It was a good movie. Romantic with a little twist. That's it, no explosions, no violence... just a little movie to get away for 2 hours.
Not as bad as everyone says. I think some stuff was unnecessary such as bringing Christian exes back and Ana and Christian relationship was so toxic and the sex scenes were too much.

reviews.review_title: OMG, it's like a romance novel from the grocery store checkout line
reviews.content: I tapped my fingers thru the first 19 minutes of formula flirtation before somebody's clothes came off. There, that ends my "spoiler".I gave the 4 stars for the costuming of Dakota Johnson who is often wearing a sensational collection of lingerie on her finely honed body. The remaining 95 minutes of the film followed the direction of the venerable master Ben Wa: put the best qualities in a box, shake them about and pull out the best as often as one needs to capture our attention.

Review: I really didn't like this movie because it offered absolutely nothing for me. The direction and screenplay really aren't all that great. The casting and acting really aren't that great either. The acting is especially bad because Jamie Dornan and Dakota Johnson are absolutely terrible due to zero chemistry. Also this movie was not porn like was promised due to the book.

reviews.review_title: As a woman I really loved it
reviews.content: I was able to feel something from this adaptation of the novel. I loved it some people will just judge it butIF U LIKED THE BOOKS U WILL LIKE THE MOVIE they did a great job!I can't wait to see the next one! By the way at end credits there is a trailer for the next movie.I Am Not Gonna Spoil The MovieDon't listen to others enjoy it for what it brings.Only thing I would have liked to see is more of Christian Grey.The commercial was also good.There was plenty of sex scenes and story. I wish the movie was longer.

Seriously one of the worst I have seen , everything looks like horrible acting of a silly sop opera that was made in the 90s And since when people crash and go back to their homes , at least give us the hospital part !!! The fun part thou I enjoyed was that I was predicting every single line , and it worked 90% of the time , just put your head in a very bad acting mode and Vola !!!

reviews.review_title: The sexy Christian gray we asked for has arrived recommend if for nothing but him
reviews.content: Fifty shades darker was so much better than the first. It was sexy and funny and oh so yummg. So much better than the first fifty Shades of gray. Don't go into it expecting a play by play of the book though. The movie does change up some of the original story, but overall it was for the best. Their chemistry was so good in this one compared to the first film. Jamie Dornan really upped his A game and his body was smoking hot. The tough sexy strong Christian Gray we asked for from the first film showed up and brought it all. The scenes seemed to flow better. Their love scenes were believable and so steamy. This one brought more of what we loved in the book to the screen. If you think Jamie Dornan is as good looking as I do, you should go see the movie. Loved it! Way to go Jamie!

This is the first review I am writing of a movie I left in the middle. I often think one should only review a movie that he/she has watched to its end. Normally but with these sort of movies I just give a one star rate and don't bother with review. But this time, I feel I need to make an exception. Oh dear Lord, this movie is not only bad but story-less, script-less and pointless. After failure of first movie, WHY on earth would they make it again? And without learning from their mistakes! Let me sum the movie up for you Christian: I am dark, mysterious and like to act like an 'a-hole'. - Anastasia: I am girly, weak, fragile, cute and a mess. That's it. That is what the whole movie is about! Don't watch it. You will regret it.

Well, the first one raped my intelligence, so now I'm pretty dumb. This one was excellent to the point that it raped my intelligence once again. This one screwed my brains in, out, left, right and in any other directions you can think of. I believe that with this film, Jamie and Dakota Johnson can both win a Razzie each to boost their career to greater heights. Best movie of the year. 10/10

reviews.review_title: Handsome sex scenes, but this is it. Don't forget, this is porn, for visual pleasure, not a well-thought trough film. Take it as this and have some fun.
reviews.content: A tiny bit better than the first one, with more tension and still a great amount of sex scenes, but I must admit, that was it - again. Overall, the story arc is cheap and the characters are not deep. But still pleasant to watch for some nice kink, if you look over the fact that what's represented on screen is not even real BDSM. If you reflect this well, it's nice to look at. but nothing, I repeat, nothing more.

reviews.review_title: Sadly no improvement from the first try.
reviews.content: I confess that curiosity got the better of me, and I had to see if this sequel might improve on the faults of the original. Sadly, it didn't. The things that made the first movie poorly produced were still there. Even with another 2 hours of screen time we never get any closer to knowing these characters better. They are just as superficial as they were in the first film. Again, there are scenes that don't make common sense. In this case, the worst example is the emergency event involving Grey's travel and what happens afterwards. That whole sequence was just plain silly. And, of course we once again get an ending that proves they intend to make another sequel. How blatant can you get?

reviews.review_title: This wasn't Fifty Shades at all
reviews.content: The acting and casting was good in this film and it was a nice story with some sex scenes but this wasn't Fifty Shades Darker nor was the character Jamie Dornan played, Christian Grey, not even close. This film was so far removed from the books it was a shockingly terrible adaptation. As mentioned the actors did a good job with what they had to work with, but the writers made a joke of the original story and characters, no turmoil over Christian being a dominant but wanting a loving relationship, no getting to understand the conflict both Christian and Anna go through with his past and no Doctor Flynn. Just how did E L James sign this off????

I'm a bit mixed about this movie. I think they focussed a bit too much on the erotics and not so much on the story. The acting was ok, because I think that was how the characters were meant to be. Just a bit slow in the beginning. I didn't read the books but it felt that they could have gotten more out of the story? The girl, Leila, background of Grey complicated life. But maybe that's for part three.
